synonyms: Magnesium bisglycinate; as Magnesium Glycinate; Magnesium diglycinate; MgG
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs support magnesium supplementation for sleep quality, mood, and muscle function. Glycinate form shows superior tolerability and bioavailability versus oxide; specific perimenopause RCTs limited but sleep and anxiety benefits broadly demonstrated.
dose_notes: Glycinate form has higher bioavailability than oxide; split doses improve absorption; upper tolerable limit 350mg supplemental per day (EU/UK); take with food to reduce GI effects.
research_gaps: No large RCTs specifically in perimenopausal women measuring hot flush frequency or hormonal outcomes.

synonyms: Mag oxide; MgO; as Magnesium Oxide
evidence_summary: RCTs show modest benefit for constipation and migraine prevention. Bioavailability significantly lower than organic forms (~4%); limited evidence for mood or sleep at typical supplement doses.
dose_notes: Poor bioavailability (~4%); primarily acts as osmotic laxative at higher doses; not recommended as preferred form for systemic magnesium repletion.
research_gaps: No head-to-head RCTs comparing forms specifically in perimenopausal populations.

synonyms: Magnesium citrate anhydrous; as Magnesium Citrate
evidence_summary: RCTs support use for constipation and kidney stone prevention. Intermediate bioavailability (~25%); commonly used in sleep and relaxation formulas though RCT evidence for these outcomes is thinner than for glycinate form.
dose_notes: Better absorbed than oxide; commonly used in powder drink formats; may have mild laxative effect at doses above 400mg.
research_gaps: Limited direct comparison RCTs between citrate and glycinate for mood and sleep outcomes.

synonyms: Dimagnesium malate; as Magnesium Malate
evidence_summary: Small RCTs suggest benefit for fibromyalgia pain and fatigue. Malic acid component may support mitochondrial energy production. Limited perimenopause-specific evidence.
dose_notes: May be particularly suited to energy and fatigue applications due to malic acid component; limited safety data at high doses long-term.
research_gaps: No RCTs in perimenopausal women; fibromyalgia evidence not directly translatable.

synonyms: Magnesium ditaurate; as Magnesium Taurate
evidence_summary: Very limited human RCT data. Theoretical cardiovascular and neurological benefits from combined magnesium and taurine. Animal data more extensive than human trials.
dose_notes: Taurine component may offer additional cardiovascular benefit; limited human RCT data limits dosing guidance.
research_gaps: Almost no human RCT data; clinical utility versus other forms unestablished.

synonyms: As Calcium Carbonate; CaCO3; chalk
evidence_summary: Strong evidence for bone density maintenance when combined with vitamin D. Carbonate form requires stomach acid for absorption; less effective in older women with reduced gastric acid. Excess calcium supplementation associated with cardiovascular risk in some meta-analyses.
dose_notes: Must be taken with food to optimise absorption; split doses of 500mg improve uptake; total calcium intake (diet + supplement) should not exceed 2500mg/day.
research_gaps: Long-term cardiovascular safety of calcium supplementation in perimenopausal women remains debated.

synonyms: As Calcium Citrate; calcium citrate tetrahydrate
evidence_summary: Superior absorption to carbonate particularly in achlorhydria and post-menopausal women with reduced gastric acid. RCTs support bone density maintenance. Preferred form for women over 50.
dose_notes: Can be taken without food; better absorbed than carbonate in women with low stomach acid; useful for post-bariatric patients.
research_gaps: Head-to-head fracture outcome RCTs comparing citrate vs carbonate specifically in perimenopause are lacking.

synonyms: Cholecalciferol; as Vitamin D3; Colecalciferol; Vigantol
evidence_summary: Extensive RCT and meta-analysis evidence for bone health, immune function, and mood when deficient. Evidence for reducing fracture risk is strong when combined with calcium. Some RCTs show mood benefit in deficient individuals. Perimenopause-specific bone and mood data available.
dose_notes: Requires cofactors (K2, magnesium) for optimal calcium metabolism; fat-soluble so take with food; 25(OH)D blood level testing recommended before high-dose supplementation; UK NHS advises 400IU daily for general population.
research_gaps: Optimal dosing for perimenopause-specific outcomes (beyond deficiency correction) not yet established in large RCTs.

synonyms: Ergocalciferol; as Vitamin D2; Ergocalciferolum
evidence_summary: Less potent than D3 at raising serum 25(OH)D; RCTs show it raises blood levels but less efficiently. Suitable for vegans. Most bone health RCT evidence generated with D3 form.
dose_notes: D3 is approximately 87% more potent than D2 at raising serum 25(OH)D levels; D2 suitable for vegans/vegetarians but D3 preferred clinically.
research_gaps: Comparative RCTs of D2 vs D3 specifically for perimenopause outcomes (bone mood cognition) are lacking.

synonyms: Menaquinone-7; MK-7; as Vitamin K2 MK-7; Natto-derived K2
evidence_summary: RCTs show K2 MK-7 activates osteocalcin and matrix Gla protein, improving bone mineral density and reducing arterial calcification. MK-7 has longer half-life than MK-4. Perimenopause bone density RCTs exist.
dose_notes: Take with fat-containing meal; interacts with warfarin and anticoagulants — contraindicated; MK-7 has superior half-life (72h vs 1-2h for MK-4); 90mcg EU NRV is below therapeutic bone-protective doses used in trials.
research_gaps: Long-term fracture outcome RCTs specifically in perimenopausal women are lacking; optimal dose above NRV unconfirmed.

synonyms: Menatetrenone; MK-4; as Vitamin K2 MK-4
evidence_summary: RCTs primarily from Japan using high doses (45mg) show reduced fracture risk. Lower doses used in supplements have less evidence. MK-4 has shorter half-life requiring more frequent dosing.
dose_notes: High therapeutic doses (45mg) used in Japanese trials are far above typical supplement levels; standard supplement doses (100–200mcg) have limited supporting RCT evidence.
research_gaps: Most evidence from high-dose pharmaceutical use in Japan; applicability of low-dose supplement levels unclear.

synonyms: Phylloquinone; Phytonadione; as Vitamin K1
evidence_summary: RCT evidence mainly for coagulation and some bone support. Less cardiovascular-protective than K2 forms. Low risk of supplementation but competes with warfarin.
dose_notes: Interacts with anticoagulant medications including warfarin; take with fat-containing food; K1 is primarily hepatic (clotting) while K2 acts peripherally (bone/arterial).
research_gaps: Limited perimenopause-specific RCTs compared to K2 forms.

synonyms: L-ascorbic acid; Ascorbic acid; as Vitamin C; Sodium ascorbate; Calcium ascorbate; Ester-C; ascorbyl palmitate
evidence_summary: Extensive evidence for immune function, collagen synthesis, and antioxidant activity. RCT evidence for reducing common cold duration modest. Limited perimenopause-specific trials but collagen and oxidative stress relevance is indirect.
dose_notes: High doses (>1000mg) may cause GI upset; tolerable upper limit 2000mg/day; buffered forms (sodium ascorbate, Ester-C) gentler on stomach; time-release forms maintain plasma levels; take with iron to enhance non-haem absorption.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs measuring hot flush or hormonal outcomes are absent.

synonyms: Thiamine; Thiamine HCl; Thiamine mononitrate; as Vitamin B1; Benfotiamine
evidence_summary: RCTs support thiamine for energy metabolism and neurological function. Benfotiamine (fat-soluble form) shows better bioavailability and neuroprotective properties. Deficiency common in women with high carbohydrate diets or alcohol use.
dose_notes: Benfotiamine has superior bioavailability versus water-soluble thiamine HCl; water-soluble forms excreted rapidly so consistent intake important.
research_gaps: No RCTs specifically examining thiamine supplementation in perimenopausal women.

synonyms: Riboflavin; Riboflavin 5-phosphate; as Vitamin B2
evidence_summary: RCT evidence supports riboflavin for migraine prevention (400mg/day). Essential for energy metabolism and activating other B vitamins. May cause harmless bright yellow urine at supplement doses.
dose_notes: Migraine prophylaxis requires 400mg/day — far above NRV; may be less effective in MTHFR mutation carriers who need active forms; take with food.
research_gaps: No RCTs specifically in perimenopausal migraine sufferers.

synonyms: Niacin; Nicotinic acid; as Vitamin B3; Niacinamide; Nicotinamide
evidence_summary: Strong evidence for cholesterol management at pharmacological doses (1000-3000mg). Niacinamide (nicotinamide) does not cause flushing and has some skin and joint evidence. RCT evidence at supplement doses for energy or mood is thinner.
dose_notes: High-dose niacin (>500mg) causes flushing — use flush-free niacinamide or extended-release forms for supplement purposes; liver toxicity possible at high doses; time-release forms have higher hepatotoxicity risk.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific outcomes beyond lipid management not studied in RCTs.

synonyms: Nicotinamide; Niacinamide; as Nicotinamide; as Niacinamide
evidence_summary: RCTs show nicotinamide effective for skin conditions (acne, rosacea) and may reduce skin cancer risk. No flushing effect unlike niacin. Limited evidence for energy or cognitive benefits at supplement doses.
dose_notes: Does not cause niacin flush; preferred form for general supplementation; high doses (>3000mg) associated with nausea and hepatotoxicity.
research_gaps: Long-term safety data above 500mg/day in perimenopausal women is lacking.

synonyms: Pantothenic acid; D-pantothenic acid; Calcium pantothenate; as Vitamin B5; Panthenol
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for standalone supplementation; essential for CoA synthesis and energy metabolism. Topical panthenol has strong skin evidence. No meaningful perimenopause-specific trials.
dose_notes: Generally well tolerated; no established upper tolerable limit; deficiency is rare on balanced diet.
research_gaps: Virtually no RCTs examining supplemental B5 for perimenopause-relevant outcomes.

synonyms: Pyridoxine HCl; Pyridoxal-5-phosphate; P5P; as Vitamin B6; as Pyridoxine
evidence_summary: Strong evidence for PMS symptom relief and nausea in pregnancy. RCTs support mood and hormonal balance benefits relevant to perimenopause. P5P (active form) does not require hepatic conversion. Upper tolerable limit important — neuropathy risk at high doses.
dose_notes: P5P is the active coenzyme form and preferred for those with liver issues; neuropathy risk above 200mg/day long-term; EU upper tolerable limit 25mg/day; EFSA health claim approved for protein and glycogen metabolism.
research_gaps: RCTs in perimenopause specifically for mood and vasomotor symptoms are limited; optimal form comparison needed.

synonyms: Biotin; D-Biotin; as Vitamin B7; as Biotin
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for hair/nail strength at 2500-5000mcg; widely marketed but evidence for hair loss in non-deficient individuals is weak. Can interfere with thyroid and troponin immunoassay lab tests.
dose_notes: Can falsely alter thyroid hormone lab results (TSH, T4) — advise stopping 48-72h before blood tests; deficiency rare; widely over-supplemented relative to evidence base.
research_gaps: No well-powered RCTs demonstrate hair growth benefit in women without biotin deficiency.

synonyms: Folic acid; Folate; as Vitamin B9; as Folic Acid
evidence_summary: Strong evidence for neural tube defect prevention in pregnancy. RCTs support cardiovascular and mood benefits, particularly in MTHFR variants. Perimenopause relevance includes cardiovascular protection and cognitive support. High doses may mask B12 deficiency.
dose_notes: MTHFR C677T and A1298C variants impair conversion of folic acid to active methylfolate; prefer methylfolate in these populations; EU upper tolerable limit 1000mcg/day; mask B12 deficiency at high doses.
research_gaps: MTHFR variant-specific dosing guidance in perimenopausal populations not established.

synonyms: 5-MTHF; L-methylfolate; 5-methyltetrahydrofolate; Metafolin; Quatrefolic; as Methylfolate
evidence_summary: Active form of folate that bypasses MTHFR conversion step. RCTs show benefit for depression and mood, particularly in MTHFR variants. Superior to folic acid for homocysteine lowering in some populations.
dose_notes: Preferred form for individuals with MTHFR variants; may cause anxiety or overstimulation in some at high doses; more expensive than folic acid but more bioavailable for at-risk groups.
research_gaps: Large RCTs comparing methylfolate vs folic acid for perimenopause mood outcomes are absent.

synonyms: Cyanocobalamin; as Vitamin B12; as Cyanocobalamin
evidence_summary: Strong evidence for neurological function, energy metabolism, and megaloblastic anaemia prevention. Absorption declines with age due to reduced intrinsic factor. Cyanocobalamin requires hepatic conversion to active forms.
dose_notes: Sublingual or spray forms bypass gastric absorption issues; higher doses needed as oral absorption relies on intrinsic factor which declines with age; cyanocobalamin less preferred for those with MTHFR or renal issues.
research_gaps: Optimal dose and form for age-related absorption decline in perimenopausal women not established.

synonyms: Methylcobalamin; as Methylcobalamin; active B12
evidence_summary: Active form of B12 that does not require hepatic conversion. Evidence for neurological protection and sleep regulation. May be superior for neurological applications and those with MTHFR variants.
dose_notes: Preferred for neurological applications and methylation support; sublingual form may improve absorption in individuals with intrinsic factor deficiency; more stable in formulations than hydroxocobalamin.
research_gaps: Direct comparison RCTs of methylcobalamin vs cyanocobalamin for perimenopause-specific outcomes lacking.

synonyms: Retinol; Retinyl palmitate; Retinyl acetate; as Vitamin A; Preformed Vitamin A
evidence_summary: Essential for vision, immune function, and skin health. RCTs for supplementation mainly in deficiency populations. Teratogenic at high doses. Fat-soluble — accumulates to toxic levels.
dose_notes: Upper tolerable limit 3000mcg RAE (10000 IU); teratogenic — avoid high doses in women of reproductive age; fat-soluble accumulation risk with long-term supplementation; take with fat.
research_gaps: Toxicity threshold in perimenopausal women with concurrent high dietary retinol intake not well characterised.

synonyms: β-Carotene; Provitamin A; as Beta-Carotene
evidence_summary: Precursor to vitamin A; conversion rate variable (genetic and dietary factors). RCT evidence for cancer prevention largely negative (CARET trial). Antioxidant benefits at low doses. High-dose supplementation in smokers associated with increased lung cancer risk.
dose_notes: Conversion to retinol is highly variable; does not accumulate to toxic levels like preformed vitamin A; avoid high-dose supplementation in current smokers.
research_gaps: CARET trial findings on lung cancer risk in smokers limit broader use; perimenopause-specific safety data lacking.

synonyms: d-alpha-tocopherol; dl-alpha-tocopherol; Mixed tocopherols; as Vitamin E; Tocopheryl acetate
evidence_summary: Some RCTs show modest benefit for hot flushes and oxidative stress in perimenopause. Mixed tocopherols (including gamma-tocopherol) may be superior to alpha-tocopherol alone. High doses associated with increased bleeding risk.
dose_notes: Natural d-alpha-tocopherol has higher bioavailability than synthetic dl-alpha-tocopherol; mixed tocopherols preferred; upper tolerable limit 1000mg/day; bleeding risk at high doses; may interact with anticoagulants.
research_gaps: Optimal dose and form comparison RCTs for perimenopause hot flush outcomes are limited.

synonyms: Ferrous bisglycinate; Ferrochel; as Iron Bisglycinate; chelated iron
evidence_summary: Superior bioavailability versus iron sulfate/fumarate with significantly less GI side effects. RCTs demonstrate equivalent or superior haemoglobin restoration at lower doses. Preferred form for women with iron-deficiency anaemia.
dose_notes: Take on empty stomach or with vitamin C for best absorption; coffee, tea, calcium reduce absorption; bisglycinate has approximately 2-4x higher bioavailability than ferrous sulfate allowing lower effective doses; do not co-supplement with calcium.
research_gaps: Long-term RCTs comparing forms specifically in perimenopausal women with varying menstrual patterns are lacking.

synonyms: Ferrous fumarate; as Iron Fumarate; as Ferrous Fumarate
evidence_summary: Well-established form for iron deficiency anaemia. More GI side effects than bisglycinate. Widely used in NHS prescribing. Evidence base comparable to sulfate.
dose_notes: Higher GI side effects than glycinate forms; take with food to reduce side effects at cost of some absorption; widely available and cost-effective.
research_gaps: Direct head-to-head comparison with bisglycinate in perimenopausal women specifically is lacking.

synonyms: Zinc bisglycinate chelate; as Zinc Bisglycinate; chelated zinc; Zinc glycinate
evidence_summary: Highly bioavailable form of zinc. RCTs support immune function, skin health, and hormonal balance. Zinc plays role in thyroid hormone metabolism and reproductive hormone regulation. Better tolerated than zinc sulfate.
dose_notes: Bisglycinate has superior absorption and tolerability versus zinc sulfate or oxide; upper tolerable limit 25mg/day (UK); take with food to prevent nausea; separate from iron and calcium by 2+ hours.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs examining zinc's role in hormonal transitions are limited.

synonyms: Zinc gluconate; as Zinc Gluconate
evidence_summary: Good bioavailability form; RCTs support immune function and cold duration reduction. Commonly used in immune supplements. Similar efficacy to bisglycinate but slightly lower bioavailability.
dose_notes: Generally well tolerated; take with food; separate from iron and calcium; chronic high doses may deplete copper — ensure adequate copper intake.
research_gaps: Comparative bioavailability studies versus bisglycinate form in older women are lacking.

synonyms: L-selenomethionine; Selenium as L-selenomethionine; SeMet
evidence_summary: Organic form with highest bioavailability. RCTs support thyroid function, antioxidant activity (glutathione peroxidase), and immune function. Strong evidence for thyroid health particularly in autoimmune thyroid disease. Upper limit important.
dose_notes: Selenomethionine has highest bioavailability of selenium forms; upper tolerable limit 400mcg/day; selenium toxicity (selenosis) above 400mcg; Brazil nuts are high natural source — supplementation risk if high nut consumption; thyroid dose usually 200mcg.
research_gaps: Optimal dose for perimenopausal thyroid health and combination with iodine not established.

synonyms: Sodium selenite; Selenious acid; as Selenium Selenite
evidence_summary: Inorganic form; lower bioavailability than selenomethionine. RCTs show thyroid and antioxidant benefits. Adequate but not optimal form for supplementation.
dose_notes: Lower bioavailability than organic selenomethionine; selenomethionine preferred for supplementation; risk of interaction with vitamin C at high doses reducing absorption.
research_gaps: Head-to-head comparison RCTs with selenomethionine specifically for thyroid outcomes in women are limited.

synonyms: Potassium iodide; Sodium iodide; as Iodine; Kelp iodine; Lugol's iodine
evidence_summary: Essential for thyroid hormone synthesis. Strong evidence for preventing hypothyroidism and goitre. UK population often mildly deficient, particularly women. Both deficiency AND excess impair thyroid function.
dose_notes: Upper tolerable limit 600mcg/day (EU); kelp-derived iodine has variable and often excessive content — avoid unquantified kelp sources; iodine from KI is reliable and quantified; interacts with thyroid medication and radioactive iodine treatment.
research_gaps: Optimal supplementation levels for perimenopausal women with subclinical thyroid dysfunction not established.

synonyms: Chromium picolinate; as Chromium Picolinate; trivalent chromium
evidence_summary: RCTs show modest benefit for glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity. Some evidence for reducing carbohydrate cravings. Perimenopause relevance for metabolic changes and insulin resistance. Picolinate form has superior absorption.
dose_notes: Picolinate form preferred for bioavailability; take with meals; evidence for weight management is inconsistent across RCTs; upper tolerable limit not well established for trivalent chromium; hexavalent chromium is carcinogenic (not present in supplements).
research_gaps: Long-term RCTs for chromium supplementation in perimenopausal metabolic changes are absent.

synonyms: Boron; as Boron Glycinate; FruiteX-B; calcium fructoborate
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence but boron influences bone metabolism, oestrogen metabolism, and cognitive function. May increase oestrogen levels in postmenopausal women. Fruit form (calcium fructoborate) has proprietary study data.
dose_notes: Doses above 20mg/day may cause toxicity; FruiteX-B (calcium fructoborate) has more human study data than boron glycinate; potential oestrogenic effect warrants caution in hormone-sensitive conditions.
research_gaps: Limited independent RCTs; most evidence from small or industry-funded studies.

synonyms: Copper bisglycinate; as Copper Gluconate; as Copper; cupric gluconate
evidence_summary: Essential micronutrient; RCTs limited as deficiency is rare. Important cofactor for iron metabolism — high-dose zinc supplementation depletes copper. Copper: zinc ratio important for cardiovascular health.
dose_notes: Upper tolerable limit 5mg/day; commonly depleted by high-dose zinc (>40mg); supplement 1mg copper per 15mg zinc above maintenance levels; copper deficiency can cause neurological symptoms.
research_gaps: RCTs specifically examining copper supplementation in perimenopausal women are absent.

synonyms: Manganese; as Manganese Bisglycinate; manganese chelate
evidence_summary: Essential for bone matrix formation and antioxidant superoxide dismutase. Limited standalone RCT evidence; frequently included in bone health formulas with calcium, D3, and K2.
dose_notes: Upper tolerable limit 11mg/day; generally included in small doses as bone cofactor; bisglycinate form preferred for bioavailability.
research_gaps: No standalone RCTs for perimenopausal bone health outcomes.

synonyms: Creatine; Creatine monohydrate; CreaPure; as Creatine Monohydrate
evidence_summary: Strong RCT evidence for muscle strength and power in both athletes and older adults. Emerging RCT evidence for cognitive function, mood, and bone density in women. Meta-analyses support lean mass preservation. Recent evidence specifically in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women is growing.
dose_notes: Loading phase (20g/day for 5 days) increases stores faster but causes water retention; 3-5g/day maintenance is sufficient for most; micronised forms improve dissolution; most cost-effective as monohydrate; take post-exercise or with carbohydrates for best muscle uptake.
research_gaps: Post-2022: emerging RCT evidence specifically in perimenopausal women for cognitive and bone outcomes; long-term studies >12 months in this population needed.

synonyms: CoQ10; Ubiquinone; Ubidecarenone; as CoQ10; as Ubiquinone
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs support benefits for cardiovascular health, statin-induced myopathy relief, and energy metabolism. Evidence for fertility support in older reproductive-age women. Endogenous CoQ10 production declines with age. Statins significantly deplete CoQ10.
dose_notes: Fat-soluble — must be taken with a fatty meal; ubiquinol form may be superior for absorption in individuals over 40; soft-gel formulations improve bioavailability; divide doses if taking >100mg.
research_gaps: Optimal form comparison (ubiquinone vs ubiquinol) specifically for perimenopausal outcomes not settled.

synonyms: Ubiquinol; reduced CoQ10; Kaneka Ubiquinol; as Ubiquinol
evidence_summary: Active reduced form of CoQ10; some RCTs suggest superior absorption particularly in older adults and those with mitochondrial dysfunction. Less oxidised during digestion. Evidence base smaller than ubiquinone.
dose_notes: May have superior bioavailability in older adults compared to ubiquinone; more expensive; fat-soluble — take with food; limited head-to-head RCTs versus ubiquinone for clinical outcomes.
research_gaps: Direct comparison RCTs of ubiquinol vs ubiquinone specifically in perimenopausal women are lacking.

synonyms: ALA; R-lipoic acid; S-lipoic acid; R-ALA; as Alpha Lipoic Acid; thioctic acid
evidence_summary: RCTs support benefits for insulin sensitivity, neuropathy, and antioxidant activity. R-ALA is the biologically active form. Some evidence for weight management in PCOS. Limited perimenopause-specific trials.
dose_notes: R-ALA form is more bioavailable than racemic mixture; take on empty stomach for best absorption; may lower blood glucose — caution in diabetics; interact with thyroid medication and chemotherapy.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs examining ALA for metabolic and neuroprotective outcomes are lacking.

synonyms: Trans-resveratrol; Polygonum cuspidatum extract; as Resveratrol; Japanese knotweed
evidence_summary: RCT evidence for cardiovascular and metabolic benefits is inconsistent. Low oral bioavailability limits efficacy of many products. Some RCTs in postmenopausal women show cognitive and cardiovascular benefits. Recent evidence mixed.
dose_notes: Very low bioavailability (~1%); micronised forms or combination with piperine may improve absorption; anti-oestrogenic and pro-oestrogenic effects documented depending on concentration — caution in hormone-sensitive conditions.
research_gaps: Conflicting RCT results; bioavailability challenge limits translation from preclinical data; long-term safety in oestrogen-sensitive individuals not established.

synonyms: Nicotinamide mononucleotide; β-NMN; as NMN
evidence_summary: Early phase human RCTs show NMN raises blood NAD+ levels and may improve muscle insulin sensitivity and aerobic capacity in older adults. Evidence base is very young and most RCTs are small and short-term. Post-2022 data growing.
dose_notes: Post-2022: several small RCTs have now been published showing NAD+ elevation; long-term safety data absent; currently in regulatory grey area in some jurisdictions; FDA has raised questions about NMN's status as a dietary supplement vs investigational drug.
research_gaps: Post-2022: FDA challenged NMN's supplement status; long-term safety and efficacy RCTs absent; regulatory status uncertain in UK/EU.

synonyms: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide; as NAD+; reduced NAD
evidence_summary: Oral NAD+ has very poor bioavailability due to degradation before absorption. No meaningful human RCT evidence for oral NAD+ supplementation. NMN and NR are preferred precursor strategies.
dose_notes: Direct oral NAD+ is unlikely to significantly raise systemic NAD+ levels due to poor bioavailability; NMN and NR are more clinically rational approaches.
research_gaps: Fundamental bioavailability questions mean no meaningful clinical RCT base exists.

synonyms: NR; Niagen; as Nicotinamide Riboside; as NR
evidence_summary: Multiple small RCTs confirm NR raises blood NAD+ levels. Some RCTs show metabolic and cardiovascular benefits. Evidence base more established than NMN. Short-term safety appears acceptable.
dose_notes: Currently considered a dietary supplement in UK/EU; multiple branded forms available (Niagen); divided doses may maintain NAD+ levels more consistently; long-term safety data beyond 12 months lacking.
research_gaps: Long-term safety data and perimenopause-specific clinical outcomes not yet established.

synonyms: Berberine HCl; as Berberine; Berberine chloride; Goldenseal berberine
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs demonstrate berberine comparable to metformin for blood glucose control in T2DM. Evidence for PCOS, cardiovascular, and gut health. MHRA enforcement risk in UK as unlicensed medicine claims. Significant drug interactions.
dose_notes: Take with meals to reduce GI side effects; interacts with metformin, cyclosporine, CYP3A4 substrates; may reduce oral contraceptive efficacy; should not be used as unlicensed substitute for prescribed diabetes treatment; MHRA may classify as medicinal.
research_gaps: MHRA regulatory risk in UK for medicinal claims; drug interaction profile significant; perimenopause-specific RCTs needed.

synonyms: Pyrroloquinoline quinone; PQQ disodium salt; BioPQQ; as PQQ
evidence_summary: Very limited human RCT data. Small trials suggest cognitive and mitochondrial energy benefits. Preclinical evidence strong but human translation limited. Safety appears acceptable at low doses.
dose_notes: Very limited human RCT data; most evidence from animal studies; 10-20mg doses used in available human trials; long-term safety data absent.
research_gaps: Almost no robust human RCT evidence; translation from preclinical data to clinical benefit unestablished.

synonyms: Natural astaxanthin; Haematococcus pluvialis extract; as Astaxanthin
evidence_summary: RCTs show antioxidant, skin, and eye health benefits. Some cardiovascular evidence. Anti-inflammatory properties studied in small RCTs. Generally well tolerated.
dose_notes: Fat-soluble — take with food; natural (algae-derived) astaxanthin more bioavailable than synthetic; most RCTs use 4-12mg doses; no established upper tolerable limit.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are absent; optimal dosing for skin and cognitive outcomes in women 40-55 not established.

synonyms: Lutein; FloraGLO Lutein; as Lutein; Carotenoid
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs support lutein for macular degeneration prevention and eye health (AREDS2 trial). Some evidence for cognitive function. Fat-soluble carotenoid.
dose_notes: Fat-soluble — take with food; free form lutein (vs lutein ester) may have more predictable bioavailability; found naturally in egg yolks and leafy greens.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs for cognitive benefit are limited; most evidence from older populations.

synonyms: Zeaxanthin; RR-zeaxanthin; Optisharp; as Zeaxanthin
evidence_summary: Strong evidence alongside lutein from AREDS2 for macular degeneration prevention. Often combined with lutein in eye health supplements.
dose_notes: Usually combined with lutein in a 5:1 (lutein:zeaxanthin) ratio; fat-soluble — take with food.
research_gaps: Standalone perimenopause-specific RCTs absent.

synonyms: Lycopene; Tomato extract; as Lycopene
evidence_summary: Some RCTs for prostate health (primarily male evidence). Female data limited — some cardiovascular and skin benefits. Largely safe at dietary supplement doses.
dose_notes: Fat-soluble; cooked tomato products have higher lycopene bioavailability than raw; may weakly reduce anticoagulant effects.
research_gaps: Female-specific perimenopause RCTs are almost entirely absent.

synonyms: EPA; Eicosapentaenoic acid; Fish oil EPA; as Omega-3 EPA; Icosapentaenoic acid
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs and meta-analyses support EPA for cardiovascular health, triglyceride reduction, and anti-inflammatory effects. Some evidence for mood and depression, particularly EPA-dominant formulas. Perimenopause relevance for cardiovascular risk and mood.
dose_notes: Enteric coating reduces fishy burps; take with food; anticoagulant effect at doses above 3g/day — caution with warfarin; oxidation important — choose quality assured products; prescription-strength EPA (Vascepa/Icosapent ethyl) distinct from supplement EPA.
research_gaps: Optimal EPA:DHA ratio for perimenopausal mood and cardiovascular outcomes not established.

synonyms: DHA; Docosahexaenoic acid; Fish oil DHA; as Omega-3 DHA; Algal DHA
evidence_summary: Strong RCT evidence for cognitive development, eye health, and cardiovascular benefits. Algal DHA available as vegan source. Important for brain health and myelin maintenance. Perimenopause cognitive benefit evidence emerging.
dose_notes: Vegan algal DHA is equivalent bioavailability to fish oil DHA; enteric coating reduces fishy burps; anticoagulant effect at high doses; DHA more important for cognitive applications; EPA more important for mood/cardiovascular.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs for cognitive outcomes comparing EPA vs DHA-dominant formulas are limited.

synonyms: Gamma-linolenic acid; Evening Primrose Oil GLA; Borage oil GLA; as GLA
evidence_summary: RCTs show benefit for PMS, breast pain (mastalgia), and skin hydration. Some evidence for hot flush reduction in perimenopause from evening primrose oil RCTs. Evidence less consistent than omega-3.
dose_notes: Source matters — borage oil has higher GLA content than evening primrose; take with food; may mildly inhibit platelet aggregation at high doses; beneficial effects typically require 6-8 weeks supplementation.
research_gaps: Head-to-head RCTs comparing GLA sources (EPO vs borage) for perimenopause outcomes are limited.

synonyms: Alpha-linolenic acid; ALA; Flaxseed oil ALA; as ALA; as Alpha-Linolenic Acid
evidence_summary: Plant-based omega-3 precursor; conversion to EPA/DHA is poor (~5-10% to EPA, <1% to DHA). RCTs show cardiovascular benefits but weaker than preformed EPA/DHA. Important for vegans.
dose_notes: Very poor conversion to long-chain EPA/DHA; recommended as adjunct to EPA/DHA rather than replacement; flaxseed oil is richest ALA source; does not substitute for preformed EPA/DHA for cognitive or mood applications.
research_gaps: Conversion efficiency variation between individuals not well characterised; insufficient substitute for EPA/DHA in perimenopause.

synonyms: PS; Soy-derived PS; Sunflower PS; as Phosphatidylserine
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs show cognitive benefits, particularly for memory, attention, and mood. Evidence for HPA axis modulation and cortisol reduction. Perimenopause relevance for cognitive decline prevention and stress response. Originally bovine-derived; now soy or sunflower.
dose_notes: Soy and sunflower-derived PS widely used; bovine-derived PS no longer used due to BSE; take with food; some evidence for improved cognitive outcomes in mild cognitive impairment; typically 100-400mg/day in RCTs.
research_gaps: Long-term RCTs specifically in perimenopausal women for cognitive and mood outcomes are lacking.

synonyms: PC; Lecithin PC; as Phosphatidylcholine; Alpha-GPC precursor
evidence_summary: Important for cell membrane integrity, liver health, and acetylcholine synthesis. RCTs show benefit for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. Cognitive applications less well studied than phosphatidylserine.
dose_notes: Found in lecithin (soy or sunflower); component of Alpha-GPC; choline conversion important for methylation; take with food.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific cognitive RCTs are lacking.

synonyms: Soy lecithin; Sunflower lecithin; as Lecithin
evidence_summary: Contains phosphatidylcholine and other phospholipids. Limited standalone RCT evidence but provides dietary choline. Used in emulsification. Some evidence for cognitive and liver benefits.
dose_notes: Sunflower lecithin preferred over soy for those with soy sensitivity; contains approximately 15-25% phosphatidylcholine; quality and standardisation varies between products.
research_gaps: Insufficient standalone RCTs to assess clinical impact separate from constituent phospholipids.

synonyms: L-theanine; Suntheanine; as L-Theanine; gamma-glutamylethylamide
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs demonstrate L-theanine promotes relaxation without sedation, reduces anxiety, improves sleep quality, and enhances cognitive performance especially when combined with caffeine. Perimenopause relevance for anxiety, sleep, and cognitive fog.
dose_notes: Often combined with caffeine in a 2:1 ratio (theanine:caffeine) for cognitive enhancement; well tolerated; no known toxicity; Suntheanine is patented L-form; effects within 30-60 minutes for acute anxiety relief.
research_gaps: Long-term RCTs specifically examining perimenopause anxiety and cognitive outcomes are limited.

synonyms: 5-hydroxytryptophan; L-5-HTP; as 5-HTP; Griffonia simplicifolia extract
evidence_summary: RCTs show benefits for depression, anxiety, sleep, and appetite regulation through serotonin precursor action. Perimenopause relevance for mood, sleep, and hot flush frequency. Serotonin system implicated in vasomotor symptoms.
dose_notes: CONTRAINDICATED with SSRIs and MAOIs due to serotonin syndrome risk; take 30 minutes before bed for sleep; some evidence for hot flush reduction; start at 50mg to assess tolerance; European natural medicine guidance supports use.
research_gaps: Serotonin syndrome risk with concurrent SSRI use requires strong prescriber guidance; perimenopause-specific long-term RCTs lacking.

synonyms: L-tryptophan; as L-Tryptophan; as Tryptophan
evidence_summary: Serotonin and melatonin precursor. RCTs show benefit for sleep onset and mood. Less potent than 5-HTP but may be better tolerated. EMS outbreak history from contaminated batch in 1989 — high-quality sourcing critical.
dose_notes: CAUTION with SSRIs — potential serotonin syndrome; take at night with carbohydrates to improve CNS uptake; EMS (eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome) historically linked to contaminated batches; current regulations require pharmaceutical-grade sourcing.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs for hot flush and sleep outcomes limited; manufacturing quality concerns persist historically.

synonyms: Gamma-aminobutyric acid; as GABA; PharmaGABA
evidence_summary: Oral GABA has poor blood-brain barrier penetration, limiting CNS efficacy of oral supplementation. PharmaGABA (naturally fermented form) shows some limited sleep and relaxation evidence. Mechanism of action for oral GABA in brain is debated.
dose_notes: Blood-brain barrier penetration is disputed; PharmaGABA may work via gut-brain axis or peripheral mechanisms; generally well tolerated; L-theanine and glycine may be more evidence-based alternatives for sleep/anxiety.
research_gaps: Fundamental questions about oral bioavailability and CNS penetration remain unresolved.

synonyms: Glycine; as Glycine; amino acid glycine
evidence_summary: RCTs show glycine (3g before bed) improves subjective sleep quality and reduces fatigue. Anti-inflammatory and collagen synthesis roles. Generally very well tolerated and inexpensive.
dose_notes: 3g before bed for sleep evidence; component of collagen (one-third of collagen amino acid content); well tolerated; can be added to hot drinks easily; synergistic with magnesium glycinate formulations.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs for sleep and cognitive outcomes are lacking.

synonyms: N-acetyl cysteine; N-acetylcysteine; as NAC
evidence_summary: Strong evidence for liver protection (paracetamol overdose treatment, standard of care). RCTs show benefits for PCOS, OCD, addiction, and respiratory conditions. Antioxidant via glutathione synthesis. Post-2022: MHRA and FDA reviewed supplement status.
dose_notes: Post-2022: FDA and MHRA have scrutinised NAC's supplement status as it is also a licensed medicine (used for paracetamol overdose); UK regulatory status in flux; separate from food supplements to medicines review; avoid in active peptic ulcer.
research_gaps: Post-2022: regulatory status under review by FDA and MHRA; may not remain freely available as supplement; perimenopause-specific RCTs lacking.

synonyms: Carnitine; L-carnitine; as L-Carnitine; carnitine tartrate
evidence_summary: RCTs support L-carnitine for energy metabolism, fatigue reduction, and fertility (particularly in women with PCOS). Evidence for cognitive benefits modest. More relevant in deficiency or high-demand states.
dose_notes: L-carnitine and acetyl-L-carnitine have different tissue distributions; carnitine tartrate commonly used in supplements for stability; vegetarians/vegans have lower baseline carnitine and may benefit more.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs examining fatigue and energy outcomes are lacking.

synonyms: ALCAR; Acetyl-L-carnitine; as Acetyl-L-Carnitine; ALC
evidence_summary: RCTs show cognitive benefits, particularly in mild cognitive impairment and depression in older adults. Crosses blood-brain barrier more effectively than L-carnitine. Neuroprotective properties.
dose_notes: Preferred for cognitive applications due to superior blood-brain barrier penetration; may support acetylcholine synthesis; mild interactions possible with anticoagulants (case reports).
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific cognitive RCTs are absent.

synonyms: Taurine; as Taurine; 2-aminoethanesulfonic acid
evidence_summary: RCTs show cardiovascular, blood pressure, and exercise performance benefits. Some evidence for anxiety and sleep. Generally very well tolerated. Widely present in energy drinks at doses studied in RCTs.
dose_notes: Well tolerated; no established upper tolerable limit; may augment effects of GABA-ergic sedatives; widely available and inexpensive.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are absent; optimal dosing for multiple outcomes not defined.

synonyms: Tyrosine; L-tyrosine; as L-Tyrosine; N-acetyl-L-tyrosine
evidence_summary: RCTs show benefit for cognitive performance under stress, sleep deprivation, and cold stress. Thyroid hormone precursor (converted to T3/T4). Relevant to perimenopausal cognitive and stress symptoms.
dose_notes: Thyroid hormone precursor — may affect thyroid medication requirements; take on empty stomach for best uptake; N-acetyl tyrosine has variable bioavailability; avoid in phenylketonuria; caution with MAOI and some thyroid medications.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs examining cognitive and thyroid interactions are lacking.

synonyms: Lysine; L-lysine HCl; as L-Lysine
evidence_summary: RCTs support lysine for herpes simplex virus (cold sore) suppression and calcium absorption. Essential amino acid; component of collagen. Anti-anxiety properties in some limited RCTs.
dose_notes: Commonly combined with arginine — high arginine intake may counteract lysine's herpes-suppressing effect; well tolerated; component of collagen cross-linking.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are largely absent.

synonyms: Arginine; L-arginine HCl; as L-Arginine
evidence_summary: RCTs support arginine for cardiovascular function via nitric oxide synthesis, erectile dysfunction (male evidence primarily), and exercise performance. Some female sexual function evidence. May worsen herpes outbreaks.
dose_notes: May worsen herpes simplex outbreaks; take on empty stomach; may interact with blood pressure medications and PDE5 inhibitors; high doses can cause GI upset.
research_gaps: Female sexual function RCTs in perimenopausal women using arginine are very limited.

synonyms: Glutamine; L-glutamine; as L-Glutamine
evidence_summary: RCTs support gut integrity (leaky gut), post-surgical recovery, and immune function. Most evidence in clinical settings rather than healthy supplementation. Gut lining support is main evidence-based application.
dose_notes: Take between meals for gut mucosal uptake; very well tolerated; most evidence in clinical/medical nutrition contexts rather than general wellness.
research_gaps: General wellness applications in healthy perimenopausal women not supported by strong RCT data.

synonyms: L-proline; as L-Proline
evidence_summary: Collagen amino acid; limited standalone RCT evidence. Important for wound healing and skin structure. Usually supplied via collagen hydrolysate rather than standalone supplementation.
dose_notes: Usually provided through collagen peptide supplements; isolated supplementation is uncommon in clinical practice; well tolerated.
research_gaps: No meaningful standalone RCTs; evidence derived from collagen peptide studies.

synonyms: Hydroxyl-L-proline; as Hydroxyproline; trans-4-Hydroxy-L-proline
evidence_summary: Collagen-specific amino acid; urinary hydroxyproline used as collagen breakdown marker. Minimal standalone supplementation evidence; provided through collagen hydrolysate.
dose_notes: No standalone supplement evidence; present in collagen hydrolysates; hydroxyproline-containing dipeptides may mediate collagen synthesis signalling.
research_gaps: No meaningful standalone RCT evidence; effects derived from collagen peptide research.

synonyms: Bovine collagen Type I; Marine collagen Type I; Hydrolysed collagen Type I; as Collagen Type I; collagen peptides
evidence_summary: RCTs show benefit for skin elasticity, hydration, and wrinkle reduction. Some evidence for nail and hair strength. Perimenopause relevance: oestrogen decline accelerates collagen loss. Hydrolysed forms show better absorption. Post-2022 data growing.
dose_notes: Hydrolysed collagen peptides (3-10kDa) have superior absorption; marine collagen (fish-derived) Type I most abundant; take with vitamin C to support collagen synthesis; evidence primarily for skin — bone/joint evidence mainly from Type II.
research_gaps: Post-2022: growing evidence base but optimal dose/source/peptide size for perimenopausal women not established.

synonyms: Fish collagen; Marine collagen peptides; Peptan; as Marine Collagen
evidence_summary: Predominantly Type I collagen from fish skin/scales. RCTs show skin, nail, and hair benefits. Sustainable and highly bioavailable source. Well tolerated; avoid in fish allergies.
dose_notes: Fish allergy contraindication; typically bovine collagen is alternative; Peptan is well-studied branded marine collagen; take with vitamin C; hydrolysed forms best absorbed.
research_gaps: Head-to-head comparison with bovine collagen for perimenopause-specific outcomes not available.

synonyms: Beef collagen; Bovine collagen peptides; as Bovine Collagen; collagen types I and III
evidence_summary: Contains both Type I and Type III collagen; RCTs support skin joint and bone benefits. Well tolerated. Avoid in beef allergies. Most widely studied collagen type in joint health.
dose_notes: Avoid in beef allergies; contains both Type I (skin) and Type III (skin blood vessels); pasture-raised/grass-fed sourcing is quality marker; take with vitamin C.
research_gaps: Long-term RCTs (>12 months) for bone outcomes specifically in perimenopausal women needed.

synonyms: Chicken sternum collagen; as Collagen Type II; UC-II; undenatured Type II collagen
evidence_summary: UC-II (undenatured Type II collagen) RCTs show joint cartilage and osteoarthritis benefits via oral tolerance mechanism at very low doses. Different mechanism and dose than hydrolysed collagen. Limited perimenopause bone-specific data.
dose_notes: UC-II mechanism operates at very low dose (40mg/day); mechanism is immune tolerance not amino acid supply — do not increase dose expecting greater benefit; different application from Type I/III hydrolysed collagen.
research_gaps: Perimenopause joint health RCTs specifically are limited.

synonyms: as Collagen Type III; bovine skin collagen III
evidence_summary: Type III collagen found in skin, blood vessels, and organs. Limited standalone evidence; usually provided alongside Type I in bovine collagen. Important for skin suppleness and vascular integrity.
dose_notes: Rarely supplemented in isolation; present in bovine collagen supplements; evidence attributed to Type I + III combination.
research_gaps: No standalone RCTs; effects attributed to mixed collagen type supplements.

synonyms: HA; Hyaluronan; Sodium hyaluronate; as Hyaluronic Acid
evidence_summary: Oral HA RCTs show skin hydration joint lubrication and eye dryness improvements. Perimenopause relevance for skin changes and joint discomfort. Topical evidence stronger than oral but oral evidence growing.
dose_notes: Oral bioavailability historically questioned but recent RCTs support effectiveness; lower molecular weight forms may have superior bioavailability; take with food; topical application has stronger evidence than oral for skin outcomes.
research_gaps: Optimal molecular weight and dose for oral perimenopause outcomes (skin joints vaginal dryness) not established.

synonyms: Elastin hydrolysate; as Elastin Peptides; BioElastin
evidence_summary: Very limited RCT evidence. Small studies suggest skin elasticity and joint benefits. Emerging area with limited independent research.
dose_notes: Very limited clinical data; usually combined with collagen peptides in anti-ageing formulas; most evidence from manufacturer-funded studies.
research_gaps: Almost no independent robust RCT evidence exists.

synonyms: Actaea racemosa; Cimicifuga racemosa; as Black Cohosh; Remifemin
evidence_summary: Most studied botanical for menopause symptoms. Multiple RCTs and meta-analyses show significant reduction in hot flushes, night sweats, and mood symptoms. Evidence specifically in perimenopausal and menopausal women. Mechanism not clearly oestrogenic.
dose_notes: Remifemin (Schaper & Brümmer) is best-studied standardised extract; standardised to triterpene glycosides; effects take 4-8 weeks; maximum 6-month continuous use recommended due to rare hepatotoxicity risk; discontinue if jaundice occurs.
research_gaps: Long-term safety data (>6 months) and safety in oestrogen-sensitive cancers remain uncertain.

synonyms: Trifolium pratense; as Red Clover; Promensil; Biochanin A; Formononetin; Daidzein; Genistein
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs show modest reduction in hot flush frequency; Promensil (standardised red clover isoflavone) has most evidence. Weaker effect than HRT. Phytoestrogenic activity — caution in oestrogen-sensitive conditions.
dose_notes: Phytoestrogenic — avoid in oestrogen-sensitive cancers (breast, endometrial) or with oestrogen-dependent conditions; effects take 8-12 weeks; Promensil and Menoflavon are best-studied standardised extracts; interacts with tamoxifen.
research_gaps: Safety in women with oestrogen-sensitive cancer or family history not established; long-term endometrial safety data limited.

synonyms: Daidzein; Genistein; Glycitein; Soy isoflavones; as Soy Isoflavones; equol
evidence_summary: RCTs show modest hot flush reduction, particularly in women who are equol producers (~30-50% of Western women). Variable response based on gut microbiome equol conversion. Bone density evidence exists.
dose_notes: Equol production (from daidzein) determines clinical response — non-producers benefit less; phytoestrogenic — caution in oestrogen-sensitive conditions; Asian dietary evidence does not directly translate to supplementation in Western populations.
research_gaps: Individual response variation based on equol-producer status makes universal dosing challenging.

synonyms: Salvia officinalis; as Sage Leaf; garden sage; Salvia extract
evidence_summary: RCTs show significant reduction in hot flush and night sweat frequency in perimenopausal women. Small number of good-quality trials. Fresh sage extract and standardised dried sage show similar effects. Well tolerated at studied doses.
dose_notes: Fresh sage leaf extract (Menosan/Menoforce) has most evidence; standardised preparations preferred; raw sage essential oil contains thujone — avoid essential oil internally; therapeutic doses of sage may mildly affect thyroid hormones; effects within 4 weeks.
research_gaps: Limited number of independent RCTs; optimal dose and long-term safety not established.

synonyms: Withania somnifera; KSM-66; as Ashwagandha; Indian ginseng; Sensoril; Winter cherry
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs with KSM-66 extract show reduced cortisol, anxiety, thyroid support, and sexual function improvement in women. Growing perimenopause-specific evidence for stress, sleep, and sexual function.
dose_notes: KSM-66 (5% withanolides) and Sensoril (10% withanolides) are best-studied standardised extracts; KSM-66 more commonly studied for sexual function and energy; Sensoril for stress/anxiety; effects within 8 weeks; avoid in autoimmune conditions; may affect thyroid — monitor TSH in hypothyroid patients.
research_gaps: Post-2022: new RCTs specifically in perimenopausal women for sexual function and sleep published; MHRA monitoring autoimmune and thyroid interactions.

synonyms: Lepidium meyenii; as Maca; Peruvian ginseng; gelatinised maca; black maca; red maca
evidence_summary: RCTs specifically in perimenopausal and menopausal women show improvements in sexual function, energy, mood, and reduction in anxiety and depression. Hormonal mechanism debated — may be adaptogenic rather than directly oestrogenic.
dose_notes: Gelatinised maca preferred for digestibility; black, red, and yellow maca have different compositions; most RCTs use 2-3.5g/day; effects take 6-12 weeks; generally well tolerated; no clear oestrogenic activity in RCTs despite traditional use in hormonal conditions.
research_gaps: Standardisation of maca preparations varies widely; optimal maca type and dose for specific perimenopausal outcomes not established.

synonyms: Asparagus racemosus; as Shatavari
evidence_summary: Ayurvedic herb with limited but promising RCT evidence for menopausal symptoms, galactagogue activity, and female reproductive health. Phytoestrogenic activity studied. Limited Western clinical trial data.
dose_notes: Phytoestrogenic activity — caution in oestrogen-sensitive conditions; limited standardisation of extracts; most evidence from Indian Ayurvedic medicine research with variable quality.
research_gaps: Very limited independent Western RCT data; standardisation of preparations poorly defined.

synonyms: Angelica sinensis; as Dong Quai; Female ginseng; Chinese angelica
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for menopausal symptoms; some traditional Chinese medicine trial evidence. Contains furanocoumarins - photosensitivity and anticoagulant interaction risk. Oestrogenic activity debated.
dose_notes: Contains furanocoumarins - photosensitivity risk; anticoagulant interaction (warfarin aspirin); oestrogen-sensitive conditions contraindicated; quality and standardisation of extracts varies significantly.
research_gaps: Reliable independent RCT evidence very limited; safety profile poorly characterised in modern populations.

synonyms: Vitex agnus-castus; as Chasteberry; Chaste tree berry; Agnus castus
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs and meta-analysis support chasteberry for PMS and cycle irregularity. Acts on dopamine and prolactin pathways. Perimenopause relevance for cycle regulation and mood. Not oestrogenic.
dose_notes: Acts on dopamine D2 receptors to reduce prolactin; Agnucaston and Mastodynon are most-studied standardised preparations; not suitable with dopamine-affecting medications; contraindicated in prolactin-dependent tumours.
research_gaps: Limited long-term RCTs in perimenopausal women specifically; interaction with hormone therapies not fully characterised.

synonyms: EPO; Oenothera biennis; as Evening Primrose Oil; GLA source; efamol
evidence_summary: RCTs show modest benefit for hot flushes, PMS, and breast pain. Contains GLA as active component. Evidence for hot flush reduction weaker than black cohosh but well tolerated.
dose_notes: Source of GLA; effects take 6-8 weeks; may mildly inhibit platelet aggregation at high doses; anticoagulant caution; perimenopause hot flush evidence from small RCTs.
research_gaps: Hot flush evidence limited to small RCTs; larger definitive trials lacking.

synonyms: Valeriana officinalis; as Valerian Root; valerian extract; Valdispert
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs and a Cochrane review show modest benefit for sleep onset and sleep quality. Evidence for anxiety and menopausal sleep specifically also exists. Effect size modest. Well tolerated.
dose_notes: Takes 2-4 weeks for full effect; standardised to valerenic acid (0.8%); may cause mild sedation — caution when driving; avoid with alcohol, benzodiazepines, or other sedatives; discontinue 2 weeks before surgery.
research_gaps: Optimal dose and long-term effectiveness in perimenopausal women specifically not established.

synonyms: Passiflora incarnata; as Passionflower; maypop
evidence_summary: RCTs show anxiolytic and sleep benefits. Comparable to low-dose benzodiazepines in some small RCTs. Generally well tolerated. Limited perimenopause-specific data.
dose_notes: May cause mild sedation — avoid with sedative medications; generally well tolerated; extract standardisation varies; effects within days for anxiety
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are lacking; most evidence from general anxiety and insomnia populations.

synonyms: Rhodiola rosea; as Rhodiola; Golden root; Arctic root; SHR-5
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs show stress adaptation, mental fatigue reduction, and burnout improvement. Adaptogenic mechanism. Perimenopause relevance for fatigue and stress resilience. SHR-5 is most-studied extract.
dose_notes: Standardised to rosavins and salidrosides (3%:1% ratio); SHR-5 extract has most evidence; stimulating — take in morning; may interact with CYP3A4 substrates; effects within 3-5 days for acute fatigue.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific long-term RCTs are limited; optimal dose and duration not established.

synonyms: Ocimum tenuiflorum; Ocimum sanctum; as Holy Basil; Tulsi; Ocimum
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for stress, blood glucose, and anti-inflammatory effects. Traditional Ayurvedic adaptogen. Limited evidence in Western populations.
dose_notes: Standardisation of extracts varies widely; blood glucose lowering — caution in diabetics on medication; limited Western quality RCT data.
research_gaps: Very limited independent Western RCT evidence for perimenopausal applications.

synonyms: Ginkgo biloba extract; EGb761; LI1370; as Ginkgo Biloba
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs and meta-analyses show cognitive benefit in age-related cognitive decline and dementia. Some evidence for sexual dysfunction and anxiety. Antiplatelet effect. EGb761 is most-studied standardised extract.
dose_notes: EGb761 (24% flavonoids, 6% terpene lactones) is most evidence-based extract; strong anticoagulant/antiplatelet effect — avoid with warfarin, aspirin, clopidogrel; potential drug interactions with CYP substrates; stop 2 weeks before surgery.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs for cognitive fog are limited; anticoagulant interaction profile requires careful prescriber guidance.

synonyms: Centella asiatica; as Gotu Kola; Indian pennywort; Brahmi (sometimes confused with Bacopa)
evidence_summary: RCTs show benefit for venous insufficiency, wound healing, cognitive function, and anxiety. Some perimenopause cognitive and skin evidence. Anti-fibrotic and collagen-stimulating properties.
dose_notes: Standardised to asiaticosides; separate from Brahmi (Bacopa monnieri) which is different plant; liver enzyme elevation reported at high doses — liver caution; take with food.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are limited; hepatotoxicity risk at high doses needs monitoring.

synonyms: Hericium erinaceus; as Lion's Mane; yamabushitake; Lion's Mane extract
evidence_summary: RCTs show cognitive benefits for mild cognitive impairment and anxiety/depression. Stimulates nerve growth factor (NGF). Perimenopause cognitive relevance. Evidence base growing post-2022.
dose_notes: Post-2022: new RCTs published supporting cognitive and mood benefits; standardised extracts (>30% beta-glucans) preferred; full-spectrum fruiting body vs mycelium have different active compound profiles; generally well tolerated; some mushroom allergy cases.
research_gaps: Post-2022: evidence base growing; perimenopause-specific long-term RCTs still needed.

synonyms: Ganoderma lucidum; as Reishi; Lingzhi; Ganoderma
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for immune modulation, sleep, and fatigue. Some anti-androgenic activity relevant to PCOS. Liver toxicity reported at high doses. Well-studied preclinically but limited robust human RCTs.
dose_notes: Triterpene and beta-glucan content varies widely between products; full-spectrum extract preferred; liver toxicity reported at high doses and with certain preparations — liver caution; anti-androgenic properties potentially relevant to PCOS.
research_gaps: Robust independent human RCTs for perimenopausal outcomes are absent; hepatotoxicity monitoring required.

synonyms: Hypericum perforatum; as St John's Wort; SJW; LI160; WS5570
evidence_summary: Strong RCT evidence for mild to moderate depression comparable to SSRIs. Multiple RCTs in menopausal women for mood and vasomotor symptoms. Significant CYP3A4/P-gp drug interactions (reduces efficacy of contraceptives, antivirals, cyclosporine, warfarin).
dose_notes: Licensed herbal medicine in UK (MHRA THR); strong drug interactions via CYP3A4 induction — reduces oral contraceptive, antiretroviral, warfarin, cyclosporine, and many other drug levels significantly; DO NOT combine with SSRIs (serotonin syndrome); photosensitivity at high doses.
research_gaps: Drug interaction profile is well characterised but patient awareness remains poor; combination with SSRIs is dangerous.

synonyms: Lavandula angustifolia; Silexan; as Lavender; lavender oil
evidence_summary: Silexan (80mg oral lavender oil) has multiple RCTs showing benefit for generalised anxiety disorder, sleep, and mixed anxiety/depression. MHRA licensed as Kalms Lavender. Perimenopause anxiety and sleep relevance.
dose_notes: Silexan (Kalms Lavender, Lasea) is MHRA-licensed anxiolytic in UK; 80mg/day dose used in RCTs; aromatotherapy evidence separate and weaker; do not use orally with other sedatives; anticoagulant interaction possible at high doses.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific long-term RCTs beyond anxiety and sleep outcomes are lacking.

synonyms: Melissa officinalis; as Lemon Balm; Melissa
evidence_summary: RCTs show anxiolytic and sleep benefits, often combined with valerian. Cognitive benefits in some small trials. Well tolerated. Antiviral (herpes simplex) topical evidence.
dose_notes: Often combined with valerian for synergistic sleep benefit; may cause mild sedation — caution with sedative medications; effects within days for acute anxiety; well tolerated at studied doses.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are lacking; most evidence from general anxiety and sleep populations.

synonyms: Humulus lupulus; as Hops; hop strobiles; 8-prenylnaringenin
evidence_summary: Some RCTs for menopausal symptoms and sleep, often combined with other botanicals. 8-prenylnaringenin (8-PN) is most potent known phytoestrogen. Oestrogenic activity significant. Often in hop-valerian combinations.
dose_notes: 8-prenylnaringenin is strongest known phytoestrogen — avoid in oestrogen-sensitive conditions; often combined with valerian and passionflower; sedative effects noted; caution in oestrogen-sensitive cancers.
research_gaps: Long-term safety in oestrogen-sensitive populations and RCT evidence quality for standalone hops is limited.

synonyms: Dioscorea villosa; as Wild Yam; Mexican yam; Dioscorea extract
evidence_summary: Wild yam contains diosgenin which is a precursor to progesterone in laboratory synthesis but this conversion DOES NOT occur in the human body. RCT evidence for menopausal symptom relief is absent or negative. Widely marketed but evidence base poor.
dose_notes: Diosgenin in wild yam cannot be converted to progesterone in the body — marketing claims of 'natural progesterone' are misleading; no meaningful RCT evidence for menopause symptom relief; caution in oestrogen-sensitive conditions due to some oestrogenic activity.
research_gaps: Evidence for claimed hormonal benefits is essentially absent; widely marketed but poorly evidenced for perimenopause.

synonyms: Trigonella foenum-graecum; as Fenugreek; methi; Testofen; Furocyst
evidence_summary: RCTs show benefit for blood glucose, libido in women, and lactation support. Testosterone-modulating and oestrogenic properties. Testofen standardised extract has female sexual function RCT evidence.
dose_notes: Oestrogenic and testosterone-modulating — avoid in oestrogen-sensitive conditions; may lower blood glucose — caution in diabetics; odour in sweat/urine is common harmless side effect; Testofen (600mg/day) has most female libido evidence.
research_gaps: Long-term safety and perimenopause-specific RCTs beyond libido are limited.

synonyms: Tribulus terrestris; as Tribulus; puncture vine; Tribulus extract
evidence_summary: RCTs show benefit for female sexual dysfunction and premenopausal/perimenopausal women specifically. Does not significantly raise testosterone in human RCTs contrary to popular claims. Ovarium compositum data.
dose_notes: Female sexual function evidence more convincing than testosterone-raising claims; standardised to saponins (protodioscin); may have mild oestrogenic activity — caution in oestrogen-sensitive conditions; most sexual function RCTs in women 40-55.
research_gaps: Standardisation of active compounds across products varies; long-term safety data limited.

synonyms: Schisandra chinensis; as Schisandra; five-flavour berry; Wu Wei Zi
evidence_summary: Limited but growing RCT evidence for liver protection, adaptogenic stress response, and some menopausal symptom relief. Traditional Chinese medicine ingredient.
dose_notes: Standardised to schisandrins and gomisins; liver-protective — ironically also liver caution at very high doses; limited Western clinical evidence; most studies from Chinese literature.
research_gaps: Limited Western independent RCTs; standardisation and quality control of preparations vary widely.

synonyms: Eleutherococcus senticosus; as Siberian Ginseng; Eleuthero; Eleutherokokk
evidence_summary: RCTs show adaptogenic benefits for stress, fatigue, and immune function. Distinct from Panax ginseng — different active compounds (eleutherosides not ginsenosides). Well tolerated.
dose_notes: Different plant from Panax ginseng; standardised to eleutherosides; generally well tolerated; mild hypertensive effect in some individuals — caution in hypertension; some evidence for menopausal fatigue.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are limited; distinction from Panax ginseng evidence often conflated.

synonyms: Korean ginseng; Asian ginseng; Ginseng; as Panax Ginseng; G115
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs for cognitive function energy immune function and menopausal symptoms. G115 standardised extract has most evidence. Some evidence for female sexual function and hot flushes.
dose_notes: G115 extract (4% ginsenosides) most evidence-based; stimulating - avoid taking late in day; may interact with warfarin and blood pressure medications; mild oestrogenic activity; avoid in oestrogen-sensitive conditions; effects within 8-12 weeks.
research_gaps: Optimal dose duration and safety in oestrogen-sensitive perimenopausal women not established.

synonyms: Glycyrrhiza glabra; as Licorice Root; DGL; deglycyrrhizinated licorice; Glycyrrhiza uralensis
evidence_summary: Standard licorice has significant oestrogenic and anti-androgenic activity. RCTs show hot flush reduction. DGL form has glycyrrhizin removed — reduced hormonal and blood pressure effects. High-dose licorice raises blood pressure and causes hypokalaemia.
dose_notes: High-dose licorice with glycyrrhizin raises blood pressure and lowers potassium — significant risk; DGL (deglycyrrhizinated) is safer for GI applications; oestrogenic activity — avoid in hormone-sensitive conditions; upper tolerable limit for glycyrrhizin is 2mg/kg/day.
research_gaps: Long-term cardiovascular safety in perimenopausal women with standard licorice not established; DGL lacks hot flush RCT evidence.

synonyms: Curcuma longa; Curcumin; BCM-95; Meriva; Theracurmin; as Turmeric; as Curcumin
evidence_summary: Multiple small RCTs show anti-inflammatory, joint, cognitive, and mood benefits. Poor bioavailability of standard curcumin limits efficacy — enhanced forms (BCM-95, Meriva, Theracurmin) have 20-185x higher bioavailability. Perimenopause relevance for inflammation and mood.
dose_notes: Standard curcumin has very poor bioavailability (<1%); always use enhanced bioavailability form (BCM-95, Meriva, Theracurmin, or with piperine); may interact with anticoagulants and chemotherapy at high doses; anti-platelet effects; liver safety at very high doses.
research_gaps: Post-2022: several perimenopause-specific mood and cognitive RCTs published with enhanced forms; optimal form and dose not standardised.

synonyms: French maritime pine bark extract; Pinus pinaster; as Pycnogenol; OPC extract
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs specifically in perimenopausal women show reduction in hot flushes, sleep improvement, and cognitive function. Antioxidant and anti-inflammatory mechanism. MASCULA and other specific trials available.
dose_notes: Standardised to OPCs; well tolerated; mild anticoagulant effect; pycnogenol has most perimenopause RCT data of any single proprietary extract; manufactured by Horphag Research.
research_gaps: Long-term safety data beyond 12 months in perimenopausal women limited; comparison to standard HRT not established.

synonyms: Proanthocyanidins; OPC; as Grape Seed Extract; Leucoselect; MegaNatural
evidence_summary: RCTs show cardiovascular, antioxidant, and blood pressure benefits. Some cognitive evidence. Commonly confused with pine bark OPCs. Standardised to proanthocyanidins.
dose_notes: Standardised to proanthocyanidins (OPCs); mild anticoagulant effect; take with food; generally well tolerated; different from red wine resveratrol though both from grapes.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are limited compared to Pycnogenol.

synonyms: Silybum marianum; as Milk Thistle; Silymarin; Legalon
evidence_summary: Strong evidence for liver protection in toxic liver injury and cirrhosis. Some evidence for fatty liver disease. EFSA and ESCOP monograph supported. Liver protective properties well established. Limited perimenopause-specific data but relevant for supplement liver safety.
dose_notes: Standardised to silymarin (70-80%); MHRA licensed products available in UK; generally very well tolerated; liver protective — important for women taking other hepatotoxic supplements (black cohosh, kava); minimal drug interactions.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific outcomes beyond liver protection not studied in RCTs.

synonyms: Bacopa; Brahmi; as Bacopa Monnieri; CDRI08; Synapsa
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs show improvements in memory, attention, and cognitive processing speed. Effects accumulate over 8-12 weeks. Well-studied extract CDRI08 (Synapsa) has most evidence. Perimenopause cognitive fog relevance.
dose_notes: Standardised to bacosides (20%); CDRI08 (Synapsa) is most evidence-based extract; effects take 8-12 weeks of consistent use; may cause GI upset — take with food; cholinergic mechanism may be relevant for cognitive fog.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific cognitive RCTs with standardised extracts are limited; optimal dose for age-related cognitive decline in women 40-55 not established.

synonyms: Alpha-glycerylphosphorylcholine; Choline alfoscerate; as Alpha-GPC; L-alpha-GPC
evidence_summary: RCTs show cognitive benefits in Alzheimer's disease and age-related cognitive decline. Acetylcholine precursor with high bioavailability. Some evidence for physical performance. Regulated as medicine in some EU countries.
dose_notes: Regulated as medicine (not supplement) in some EU countries — regulatory risk varies; 50% form requires double the dose of 99% form; generally well tolerated; supports acetylcholine synthesis important for memory.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific cognitive RCTs are limited; regulatory status varies across EU jurisdictions.

synonyms: CDP-choline; Cytidine 5-diphosphocholine; as Citicoline; as CDP-Choline; Cognizin
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs show cognitive benefits including memory, attention, and brain energy. Cognizin branded form has most evidence. Precursor to both phosphatidylcholine and acetylcholine. Well tolerated.
dose_notes: Cognizin is most-studied branded form; well tolerated; cognitive benefits seen in multiple populations including older adults; take in morning as may be activating; different mechanism from Alpha-GPC but both increase acetylcholine.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific cognitive decline RCTs are lacking.

synonyms: PS; Sharp-PS; as Phosphatidylserine; soy PS; sunflower PS
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs demonstrate memory, attention, and cognitive benefits. HPA axis regulation evidence. FDA qualified health claim for cognitive decline. Well tolerated.
dose_notes: Soy or sunflower derived (bovine no longer used); EFSA health claim recognised; take with meals; most consistent evidence of any nootropic ingredient for memory in adults.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific long-term trials are lacking; existing evidence mostly in cognitive impairment populations.

synonyms: Ethyl apovincaminate; as Vinpocetine; cavinton
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for cerebral blood flow and cognitive function. Approved as prescription medicine in Hungary and some countries. Regulatory grey area in UK/EU as supplement.
dose_notes: Regulatory status uncertain in UK/EU — may be classified as medicine rather than supplement; some evidence for cerebral blood flow; anti-platelet effects; generally well tolerated at studied doses.
research_gaps: Regulatory status in UK/EU is uncertain; limited perimenopause-specific evidence.

synonyms: as Huperzine A; Huperzia serrata extract
evidence_summary: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor; limited RCT evidence from Chinese trials for Alzheimer's and cognitive impairment. Mechanism similar to pharmaceutical cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil). Thin evidence base for healthy adult use.
dose_notes: Strong cholinesterase inhibitor — avoid with Alzheimer's medications (donepezil, rivastigmine); seizure risk at high doses; narrow therapeutic window; limited high-quality independent RCTs; regulatory caution advised.
research_gaps: Safety profile and drug interactions in perimenopausal women not established; limited independent high-quality RCTs.

synonyms: Crocus sativus; as Saffron; Affron; Safranal; Crocin
evidence_summary: Multiple small RCTs show significant antidepressant effects comparable to low-dose SSRIs for mild to moderate depression. Some perimenopause-specific data for mood and sexual function. Affron branded extract has most evidence.
dose_notes: Affron extract (3.5% lepticrosalide) has most perimenopause mood evidence; well tolerated; avoid in pregnancy (uterine stimulant); anti-platelet effects at high doses; sexual function evidence in SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction.
research_gaps: Post-2022: growing perimenopause-specific mood and hot flush evidence from Affron trials; long-term safety beyond 12 weeks limited.

synonyms: Mentha spicata; as Spearmint; spearmint tea extract
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for anti-androgenic activity in PCOS (reducing free testosterone). Relevant for perimenopausal women with androgen excess symptoms (hirsutism). Spearmint tea studies primarily.
dose_notes: Anti-androgenic through 5-alpha-reductase inhibition; most evidence from spearmint tea consumption (2 cups/day); standardised extract evidence limited; PCOS evidence most consistent.
research_gaps: Perimenopausal androgen excess RCTs specifically are very limited.

synonyms: Foeniculum vulgare; as Fennel; Fennel seed extract
evidence_summary: Very limited RCT evidence for menopausal symptom relief and dysmenorrhoea. Phytoestrogenic activity documented. Traditional women's herb with limited modern clinical evidence.
dose_notes: Phytoestrogenic — avoid in oestrogen-sensitive conditions; limited modern RCT quality; dysmenorrhoea evidence from some small trials.
research_gaps: Very limited independent RCT evidence; oestrogenic safety profile in hormone-sensitive women poorly characterised.

synonyms: Lignan; Secoisolariciresinol diglucoside; SDG; as Flaxseed Lignans; flaxseed extract
evidence_summary: RCTs show modest hot flush reduction in postmenopausal women. Phytoestrogenic lignan activity via enterolignans. Cardiovascular and gut health evidence. Generally well tolerated.
dose_notes: Converted to enterolignans (enterodiol, enterolactone) by gut bacteria — variable response depending on microbiome; whole flaxseed and lignan extract have different bioavailability; phytoestrogenic — caution in oestrogen-sensitive conditions.
research_gaps: Individual variation in lignan metabolism based on gut microbiome composition makes response unpredictable.

synonyms: Moringa oleifera; as Moringa; drumstick tree; Moringa leaf extract
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for blood glucose, anti-inflammatory, and nutritional supplementation in deficient populations. Growing interest for women's health but clinical evidence thin.
dose_notes: Nutritionally dense but clinical evidence thin; standardisation of extracts varies; blood glucose lowering — caution in diabetics; limited perimenopause-specific data.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are essentially absent; mechanistic and nutritional claims outpace clinical evidence.

synonyms: Dehydroepiandrosterone; as DHEA; prasterone; Intrarosa
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs show DHEA supplementation increases testosterone and oestrogen, improves sexual function, bone density, and mood in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women. Prescription medicine in UK. Intrarosa is licensed vaginal DHEA. Oral DHEA regulated differently.
dose_notes: Licensed as prescription medicine in UK for GSM (Intrarosa, vaginal); oral DHEA is MHRA grey area; age and baseline DHEA level important for dosing; highly hormone-active — avoid in oestrogen/androgen-sensitive cancers; 25-50mg/day commonly used in research.
research_gaps: Optimal oral dose for perimenopausal women without hormone-sensitive conditions; long-term cardiovascular safety not established.

synonyms: 7-Keto; 7-oxo-DHEA; as 7-Keto DHEA; 3-acetyl-7-oxo-DHEA
evidence_summary: Metabolite of DHEA that does not convert to sex hormones. Limited RCT evidence for weight management and immune function. Lower hormonal risk than DHEA. Limited perimenopause-specific data.
dose_notes: Does not convert to oestrogen or testosterone — potentially safer profile than DHEA; limited human RCT evidence; weight management evidence from small trials; regulatory status varies.
research_gaps: Very limited independent RCT evidence; most studies industry-funded; perimenopause-specific outcomes not established.

synonyms: as Pregnenolone; pregnenolone sulfate
evidence_summary: Master steroid hormone precursor. Very limited human RCT evidence. Highly hormone-active as precursor to DHEA, progesterone, and corticosteroids. Regulatory concerns in UK.
dose_notes: Highly hormone-active — can convert to multiple sex hormones including oestrogen, progesterone, and testosterone; very limited human RCT evidence; regulatory status in UK uncertain; avoid in hormone-sensitive conditions and cancer.
research_gaps: Almost no reliable independent human RCT evidence; regulatory status and safety profile in UK poorly established.

synonyms: as Melatonin; N-acetyl-5-methoxytryptamine; Circadin
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs and meta-analyses show melatonin effective for sleep onset, jet lag, and circadian rhythm disorders. Perimenopausal sleep disruption is a major indication. Circadin is licensed medicine in UK for >55 years. Low doses (0.5-1mg) may be equally effective as higher doses.
