dose_notes: Licensed as prescription medicine in UK above 1mg (Circadin); low doses (0.5-1mg) as effective as higher doses for sleep; exogenous melatonin may suppress endogenous production at high doses; take 30-60 minutes before desired sleep time; not recommended for under-18 without medical supervision.
research_gaps: Optimal dosing for perimenopausal sleep disruption specifically; long-term effects on endogenous melatonin production not established.

synonyms: L. acidophilus; as Lactobacillus acidophilus; NCFM; LA-5
evidence_summary: RCTs support L. acidophilus for gut dysbiosis, vaginal health, and immune function. NCFM strain has most evidence for gut. LA-5 combined with Bifidobacteria widely studied. Some evidence for vaginal pH and infection prevention.
dose_notes: Strain specificity matters — benefits of one strain do not apply to all; refrigeration often required for viability; enteric coating improves survival through stomach acid; viability at time of consumption important (check CFU guarantee at expiry not manufacture).
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific vaginal and gut microbiome RCTs are growing but underpowered.

synonyms: L. rhamnosus; LGG; Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG; as Lactobacillus rhamnosus
evidence_summary: LGG (GG strain) is one of the most studied probiotic strains globally. Strong evidence for prevention and treatment of antibiotic-associated diarrhoea. Some evidence for immune function and gut barrier integrity. Widely used clinically.
dose_notes: LGG (Culturelle) is most evidence-based strain; strain specificity critical; generally well tolerated; beneficial after antibiotic courses; effects are strain-specific — LGG evidence does not apply to all L. rhamnosus strains.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs with LGG for mood (gut-brain axis) and hormonal outcomes are limited.

synonyms: L. reuteri; RC-14; DSM 17938; as Lactobacillus reuteri
evidence_summary: RC-14 strain (with L. rhamnosus GR-1) shows strong evidence for vaginal health and UTI prevention. DSM 17938 has infant colic evidence. RC-14 perimenopause relevance for vaginal microbiome.
dose_notes: Strain identity critical — RC-14 and DSM 17938 have completely different evidence bases; RC-14 combined with L. rhamnosus GR-1 for vaginal health is well-evidenced combination; refrigeration required.
research_gaps: Perimenopausal vaginal microbiome changes and probiotic intervention RCTs are an emerging but growing area.

synonyms: L. crispatus; as Lactobacillus crispatus; LACTIN-V
evidence_summary: Dominant vaginal Lactobacillus species associated with healthy vaginal microbiome. LACTIN-V product has RCT evidence for BV prevention. Highly relevant for perimenopausal vaginal microbiome changes.
dose_notes: Natural dominant strain of healthy vaginal microbiome; colonisation challenging via oral route — may require vaginal delivery for local effect; LACTIN-V (vaginal capsule) is investigational product with RCT evidence for BV.
research_gaps: Oral supplementation route efficacy for vaginal colonisation is uncertain; perimenopausal-specific RCTs are limited.

synonyms: L. gasseri; SBT2055; as Lactobacillus gasseri
evidence_summary: SBT2055 strain has RCT evidence for abdominal fat reduction and weight management in overweight individuals. Vaginal health applications also studied. Perimenopause metabolic relevance.
dose_notes: SBT2055 strain most studied for metabolic outcomes; strain specificity critical; effects modest in RCTs; perimenopausal metabolic change relevance
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific metabolic RCTs are limited; weight reduction effects modest.

synonyms: B. longum; BB536; as Bifidobacterium longum; NCIMBi 41676
evidence_summary: RCTs show immune, allergy, and gut health benefits. BB536 strain has evidence for respiratory infections and allergy. Gut-brain axis evidence emerging. B. longum declines with age making supplementation more relevant in 40+ women.
dose_notes: BB536 is most-studied strain; Bifidobacterium species decline naturally with age — supplementation increasingly relevant in perimenopausal age group; strain specificity important.
research_gaps: Perimenopausal gut-brain axis and mood outcome RCTs specifically are lacking.

synonyms: B. breve; BR03; as Bifidobacterium breve; Bif195
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for gut health and immune function. Some infant formula evidence. Limited standalone adult evidence for perimenopause applications.
dose_notes: Strain specificity critical; limited adult RCT evidence; often included in multi-strain probiotic blends.
research_gaps: Adult and perimenopause-specific standalone RCTs are very limited.

synonyms: B. lactis; BB-12; as Bifidobacterium lactis; HN019
evidence_summary: BB-12 has strong RCT evidence for gut transit, immune function, and antibiotic-associated diarrhoea. HN019 has strong evidence for gut transit time. One of most-studied probiotic strains globally.
dose_notes: BB-12 and HN019 are distinct strains with different evidence profiles; BB-12 has strongest commercial evidence base; generally very well tolerated; CFU dose important — ensure adequate dose at expiry date, not manufacture.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs for hormonal and vaginal microbiome outcomes are limited.

synonyms: S. boulardii; as Saccharomyces boulardii; CNCM I-745; Florastor
evidence_summary: Strong RCT and meta-analysis evidence for antibiotic-associated diarrhoea and C. diff prevention. Well tolerated. Yeast-based — not affected by antibiotics (unlike bacterial probiotics). Unique profile.
dose_notes: Yeast not bacteria — not affected by antibiotic use, making it ideal during antibiotic courses; well tolerated; caution in immunocompromised patients; stored at room temperature unlike many bacterial probiotics.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific applications beyond gut health not studied in RCTs.

synonyms: Chicory inulin; FOS; as Inulin; prebiotic inulin; chicory root extract
evidence_summary: RCTs show inulin improves gut microbiome composition (bifidobacterium growth), calcium absorption, and bowel function. Prebiotic activity well established. Some evidence for glucose and lipid metabolism.
dose_notes: Start low and increase gradually to avoid gas and bloating; effective dose 5-10g/day; inulin and FOS are bifidogenic prebiotics; chicory root is main commercial source; synergistic with probiotic supplementation.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific microbiome and hormonal outcome RCTs are limited.

synonyms: Fructooligosaccharides; FOS; as FOS; as Fructooligosaccharides; short-chain FOS; scFOS
evidence_summary: Similar evidence to inulin for gut microbiome and prebiotic activity. Some evidence for mineral absorption enhancement. Bifidogenic prebiotic effect well established.
dose_notes: Similar profile to inulin; short-chain FOS (scFOS) may be better tolerated at higher doses than long-chain inulin; gas and bloating at higher doses common during adaptation.
research_gaps: Optimal dose and type for perimenopausal microbiome and hormonal metabolism are not established.

synonyms: Oat beta-glucan; Barley beta-glucan; as Beta-Glucan; 1,3/1,4-beta-glucan
evidence_summary: Strong EFSA-approved health claim for cholesterol reduction and blood glucose management. Excellent cardiovascular evidence. Immune modulation evidence from oat and yeast beta-glucans. Perimenopause cardiovascular relevance.
dose_notes: EFSA approved health claim at 3g/day for cholesterol reduction; oat and barley beta-glucans most evidence-based; yeast-derived beta-glucans (1,3/1,6) have different immune modulation evidence; soluble fibre mechanism; take with water or food.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific cardiovascular outcome RCTs using beta-glucan supplementation are limited.

synonyms: Plantago ovata husk; as Psyllium Husk; Metamucil; isabgol
evidence_summary: Strong evidence for cholesterol reduction, bowel function, and glycaemic management. EFSA health claim approved. Well tolerated soluble fibre. Also classified as bulk laxative.
dose_notes: Take with large amounts of water to prevent oesophageal obstruction; can interfere with absorption of medications — take separately from other medications/supplements by 2 hours; EFSA health claim for cholesterol at 7g/day.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs for combined gut and cardiovascular outcomes are limited.

synonyms: MCC; as Microcrystalline Cellulose; E460; Avicel
evidence_summary: Inert excipient derived from plant cellulose. No pharmacological activity. Used as tablet binder and filler. GRAS status. No health concerns at typical supplement use levels.
dose_notes: No dose considerations as pharmacologically inactive excipient; GRAS (Generally Recognised As Safe); EU food additive E460.
research_gaps: Not applicable — excipient with no therapeutic activity.

synonyms: Magnesium stearate; as Magnesium Stearate; stearic acid
evidence_summary: Inert lubricant excipient. Claims that it impairs nutrient absorption (biofilm theory) are not supported by evidence. Used at very low levels in supplements (<2%). GRAS status.
dose_notes: Used at <2% in supplements; no evidence of clinically significant absorption interference at typical use levels; anti-caking and flow agent in powder processing.
research_gaps: Not applicable — excipient with no therapeutic activity; negative claims about absorption interference are not evidence-based.

synonyms: Silica; as Silicon Dioxide; E551; amorphous silica
evidence_summary: Anti-caking agent excipient. Inert at supplement levels. Nanoparticle silicon dioxide is subject to growing regulatory scrutiny. EFSA reviewed safety.
dose_notes: Used as anti-caking agent at very low levels; EFSA has reviewed nano-SiO2 safety; conventional amorphous silica considered safe at supplement use levels.
research_gaps: Nanoparticle silicon dioxide safety under ongoing regulatory review; conventional form considered safe.

synonyms: Hydroxypropyl methylcellulose; as HPMC; hypromellose; Vcaps
evidence_summary: Plant-derived capsule material and coating agent. Suitable for vegetarians and vegans. Inert and well tolerated. GRAS status.
dose_notes: Preferred capsule material for vegetarian/vegan formulations; HPMC capsules can slow release — may affect bioavailability of enclosed ingredients in some formulations.
research_gaps: Not applicable — inert excipient.

synonyms: HPC; as Hydroxypropyl Cellulose; E463
evidence_summary: Tablet binding and film coating agent. Inert. GRAS status. No pharmacological activity.
dose_notes: Inert excipient; used as binder in tablet manufacture and film coating; GRAS.
research_gaps: Not applicable — inert excipient.

synonyms: Bovine gelatin; Porcine gelatin; as Gelatin; hard shell capsule
evidence_summary: Animal-derived capsule material. Not suitable for vegetarians, vegans, or halal/kosher unless certified. No pharmacological activity. Well tolerated.
dose_notes: Not suitable for vegetarians or vegans; porcine gelatin not suitable for Muslim or Jewish consumers — check certification; conventional hard-shell capsule material.
research_gaps: Not applicable — excipient; consumer labelling considerations important.

synonyms: as Stearic Acid; octadecanoic acid
evidence_summary: Tablet lubricant. Inert at supplement use levels. Derived from animal or vegetable sources. No pharmacological activity.
dose_notes: Check vegetable vs animal source for vegan suitability; used at very low levels as tablet lubricant.
research_gaps: Not applicable — excipient.

synonyms: as Titanium Dioxide; E171; CI 77891
evidence_summary: White coating/colouring agent. EFSA banned E171 in food in 2022 due to genotoxicity concerns. Not permitted in food in UK (post-Brexit regulations still under review). Regulatory risk HIGH.
dose_notes: Post-2022: EFSA banned E171 in EU food in 2022 due to inability to rule out genotoxicity; UK Food Standards Agency reviewing; should be avoided in new supplement formulations — significant regulatory and consumer risk.
research_gaps: Post-2022: EU food ban implemented; UK regulatory status under review — HIGH risk for inclusion in new formulations.

synonyms: as Maltodextrin; corn maltodextrin; modified starch
evidence_summary: Starch-derived carrier and bulking agent. High glycaemic index. GRAS status. Common in powder formulations as carrier. No pharmacological activity.
dose_notes: High glycaemic index - relevant for diabetic consumers; derived from corn rice or wheat - coeliac risk if wheat-derived; commonly used as spray-drying carrier for powdered extracts.
research_gaps: Glycaemic concerns for diabetic perimenopausal consumers; wheat-derived versions carry coeliac risk.

synonyms: as Carrageenan; E407; Irish moss extract
evidence_summary: Emulsifier and thickener derived from red seaweed. Subject to ongoing regulatory debate — some animal studies raise gut inflammation concerns. IARC limited carcinogenicity classification for degraded form. Food-grade carrageenan considered safe by EFSA.
dose_notes: EFSA considers food-grade carrageenan safe; degraded carrageenan (poligeenan) is not permitted in food; some consumer concern exists; avoidance in IBD patients may be prudent.
research_gaps: Ongoing debate about gut inflammation effects; precautionary avoidance may be appropriate for gut health-focused supplements.

synonyms: as Shellac; E904; lac resin
evidence_summary: Natural resin from lac insects; used as enteric or delayed-release tablet coating. Not suitable for vegans. GRAS and EU approved. No pharmacological activity.
dose_notes: Not suitable for vegans as derived from insects; used for enteric coating and extended release; may cause contact allergy in rare cases.
research_gaps: Not applicable — excipient; vegan labelling considerations important.

synonyms: Magnesium silicate; as Talc; E553b
evidence_summary: Glidant and anti-caking agent. EFSA reviewed safety — approved for food use. Concerns about asbestos contamination in cosmetic talc but pharmaceutical/food grade is tested and regulated.
dose_notes: Pharmaceutical-grade talc is tested for asbestos contamination and is regulated; cosmetic talc concerns do not directly apply to supplement-grade material; used at very low levels.
research_gaps: Consumer perception concerns despite regulatory approval; asbestos testing certification important for quality assurance.

synonyms: Delta-tocotrienol; Gamma-tocotrienol; Tocotrienol complex; as Tocotrienol; DeltaGold; EVNol
evidence_summary: RCTs show cardiovascular, bone, and anti-cancer properties. May be more potent antioxidants than tocopherols. Some evidence for hot flush reduction. Less studied than tocopherols.
dose_notes: Palm-derived (EVNol) is most common commercial source; annatto-derived (DeltaGold) provides delta-tocotrienols specifically; fat-soluble — take with food; may interfere with alpha-tocopherol absorption if co-supplemented at high doses.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific long-term RCTs for bone and cardiovascular outcomes are limited.

synonyms: Quercetin; Quercetin dihydrate; as Quercetin; EMIQ; isoquercetin
evidence_summary: RCTs show anti-inflammatory, antiviral (COVID-19 studies), cardiovascular, and allergy benefits. Poor bioavailability of standard quercetin — EMIQ and isoquercetin forms have enhanced bioavailability. Some evidence for bone health.
dose_notes: Standard quercetin has very poor oral bioavailability; EMIQ (enzymatically modified isoquercitrin) and isoquercetin have superior absorption; may interact with some drug transporters (P-gp, BCRP); generally well tolerated.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs and optimal bioavailable form not established.

synonyms: as Apigenin; chamomile apigenin; apigenin 7-glucoside
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence; potential anti-oestrogenic and anti-inflammatory effects. Sleep research interest (binds GABA-A receptors). Present in chamomile. Most evidence preclinical.
dose_notes: Limited human clinical data; potential interaction with oestrogen-sensitive conditions; research at early stage; found in chamomile tea and various plant foods.
research_gaps: Almost no human RCT evidence; preclinical data cannot be extrapolated to clinical dosing.

synonyms: Matricaria chamomilla; as Chamomile; German chamomile; Chamomile extract
evidence_summary: RCTs show mild anxiolytic and sleep benefits. Some evidence for generalised anxiety disorder. Generally very well tolerated. Ragweed allergy cross-reactivity possible.
dose_notes: Avoid in ragweed/composite plant allergy; may mildly potentiate sedative effects; generally very well tolerated; apigenin is likely active component.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are lacking; most evidence from general anxiety populations.

synonyms: Withania somnifera Sensoril; as Ashwagandha Sensoril; 10% withanolides
evidence_summary: Sensoril (Natreon) has specific RCTs for stress, cognitive function, and sleep at lower doses than KSM-66. Higher withanolide content. Both root and leaf extract used.
dose_notes: Higher withanolide content than KSM-66; root and leaf extract blend; specific Sensoril RCTs differ from KSM-66 evidence — cannot be considered interchangeable; 125-250mg dosing versus 300-600mg for KSM-66.
research_gaps: Direct comparison RCTs of Sensoril vs KSM-66 for perimenopausal outcomes lacking.

synonyms: Broccoli glucosinolates; SGS; Brassica oleracea extract; as Sulforaphane
evidence_summary: RCTs show antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and hormonal metabolism benefits (oestrogen detoxification via NRF2 pathway). Some evidence for menopausal symptom reduction and oestrogen metabolism. Bioavailability varies with food processing.
dose_notes: Myrosinase enzyme needed for sulforaphane formation from glucoraphanin — co-supplementation with myrosinase or mustard powder improves yield; broccoli sprouts have higher glucoraphanin than mature broccoli; highly relevant for oestrogen metabolism and DIM pathway.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific oestrogen detoxification RCTs and optimal dose not well established.

synonyms: Diindolylmethane; 3,3'-Diindolylmethane; as DIM; Brassica indole
evidence_summary: Some RCTs for oestrogen metabolism, promoting 2-OH oestrogen metabolites over 16-OH. Evidence for breast cancer risk reduction and hormonal balance. Highly relevant to perimenopause oestrogen metabolism.
dose_notes: Promotes beneficial oestrogen metabolite pathway (2-OHE1 vs 16-OHE1); absorption improved with microencapsulation (BioResponse DIM); may cause harmless darkening of urine; oestrogen-active — caution in oestrogen-sensitive conditions; may interact with CYP1A2 substrates.
research_gaps: Long-term perimenopause safety and impact on oestrogen-sensitive tissue not established.

synonyms: Indole-3-carbinol; as I3C; as Indole-3-Carbinol
evidence_summary: Precursor to DIM; less stable than DIM in gastric conditions. Some evidence for oestrogen metabolism and cervical health. Less reliable than DIM due to pH-dependent conversion.
dose_notes: Converts to DIM and other compounds in stomach; DIM may be preferred for more predictable pharmacokinetics; cervical dysplasia RCT evidence; oestrogen-active; caution in oestrogen-sensitive conditions.
research_gaps: DIM may be more pharmacokinetically reliable; perimenopause-specific long-term safety unclear.

synonyms: Rhodiola; Hong Jing Tian; as Rhodiola crenulata
evidence_summary: Different species from R. rosea with different active compound profile. Limited RCT evidence. Often mislabelled or substituted for R. rosea in commercial products.
dose_notes: Distinct from Rhodiola rosea; standardised to salidrosides rather than rosavins/salidroside combination; limited independent RCT evidence vs R. rosea; quality control and species authentication important.
research_gaps: Species distinction from R. rosea not always maintained in commercial products; independent RCTs very limited.

synonyms: Astragalus membranaceus; as Astragalus; Huang Qi; TA-65
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for immune function and telomere extension (TA-65 proprietary extract). Anti-ageing claims not well supported by human trial evidence. Immune modulation in oncology settings studied.
dose_notes: TA-65 is proprietary cycloastragenol extract with telomerase activation claims — limited robust independent RCT evidence; standard astragalus has better immune evidence; may interact with immunosuppressant medications.
research_gaps: Anti-ageing and telomere claims significantly outpace robust independent RCT evidence.

synonyms: Cinnamomum verum; Cinnamomum cassia; as Cinnamon Extract; ceylon cinnamon; cassia cinnamon
evidence_summary: RCTs show modest blood glucose lowering and insulin sensitising effects. Ceylon cinnamon preferred over cassia due to lower coumarin content. Some PCOS evidence. Perimenopause metabolic relevance.
dose_notes: Ceylon cinnamon has very low coumarin; cassia cinnamon has high coumarin — hepatotoxic at high doses; cassia should not be used at high supplemental doses long-term; modest evidence for glycaemic management.
research_gaps: Long-term perimenopause metabolic RCTs and safe upper dose for cassia form not established.

synonyms: Oleuropein; Olive leaf polyphenols; as Olive Leaf Extract; Olivenol; EFLA943
evidence_summary: RCTs show blood pressure lowering, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory benefits. EFLA943 standardised extract has most evidence for cardiovascular outcomes. Mediterranean diet relevance.
dose_notes: Standardised to oleuropein; EFLA943 extract has blood pressure RCT evidence; generally well tolerated; antihypertensive effect — additive with blood pressure medication.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific cardiovascular RCTs are limited; blood pressure interaction with antihypertensive medication management needed.

synonyms: Sambucus nigra; as Elderberry; Sambucol; BerryPharma
evidence_summary: RCTs show Sambucol elderberry extract reduces severity and duration of cold and flu symptoms. Immune stimulation mechanism. Well tolerated. Most evidence from cold/flu intervention studies.
dose_notes: Sambucol is most-studied standardised extract; raw elderberries contain toxic compounds — must be cooked or extracted; well tolerated at supplement doses; immune stimulation — theoretical caution in autoimmune conditions.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific immune and hormonal outcome RCTs are absent.

synonyms: Echinacea purpurea; Echinacea angustifolia; as Echinacea; coneflower
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs show modest reduction in cold incidence and duration. Evidence for immune activation. Purpurea species best studied. Well tolerated short-term. Not recommended in autoimmune conditions.
dose_notes: Echinacea purpurea has most evidence; avoid in autoimmune conditions (MS, SLE, RA); member of daisy family — ragweed allergy cross-reactivity; short courses (max 8 weeks) conventionally recommended.
research_gaps: Long-term continuous use safety and perimenopause-specific immune outcome RCTs are lacking.

synonyms: Sodium ascorbate; Calcium ascorbate; Ester-C; as Buffered Vitamin C
evidence_summary: Better tolerated by sensitive stomachs than ascorbic acid. Comparable bioavailability to standard ascorbic acid. Ester-C (calcium ascorbate with metabolites) claims superior bioavailability — evidence limited.
dose_notes: Preferred for individuals who experience GI discomfort with ascorbic acid; sodium ascorbate contributes sodium to diet — relevant for low-sodium diets; Ester-C bioavailability advantage over regular ascorbate not convincingly demonstrated.
research_gaps: Clinical superiority of buffered/Ester-C forms over standard ascorbic acid not established in head-to-head RCTs.

synonyms: Choline bitartrate; Choline chloride; as Choline; CDP-Choline precursor
evidence_summary: Essential nutrient for liver function, brain development, and methylation. Many women are deficient. RCTs show benefits for cognitive function and liver health. AI established but not formally listed as UK RNI.
dose_notes: UK does not have a formal RNI for choline; AI is 550mg/day for men, 425mg for women; choline bitartrate most common supplement form; fishy odour side effect at high doses; component of methylation cycle alongside folate and B12.
research_gaps: Choline requirements during perimenopause transition (reduced oestrogen affects hepatic choline synthesis) not well established.

synonyms: Myo-inositol; D-chiro-inositol; as Inositol; as Myo-Inositol; Ovosit
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs demonstrate myo-inositol improves insulin sensitivity and ovarian function in PCOS. Some evidence for metabolic syndrome and anxiety (as phosphoinositol). Relevant to perimenopausal insulin resistance.
dose_notes: Myo-inositol:D-chiro-inositol at 40:1 ratio mirrors physiological ratio in many PCOS RCTs; anxiety evidence at higher doses (18g/day); well tolerated; not the same as inositol hexaniacinate (different compound); relevant for perimenopausal metabolic change.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific metabolic syndrome and insulin resistance RCTs are limited.

synonyms: as Glucosamine Sulfate; glucosamine HCl; DONA; N-acetylglucosamine
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs and a Cochrane review show glucosamine sulfate reduces knee OA pain and may slow cartilage degradation. DONA (1500mg/day crystalline glucosamine sulfate) has strongest evidence. Joint pain is common perimenopause symptom.
dose_notes: DONA crystalline glucosamine sulfate (Rottapharm/Madaus) has most evidence at exactly 1500mg/day; glucosamine HCl has less RCT support; sulfate form preferred; may slightly affect blood glucose — caution in diabetes; derived from shellfish.
research_gaps: Long-term perimenopause-specific joint health RCTs not available; most OA evidence from general adult populations.

synonyms: as Chondroitin Sulfate; chondroitin; bovine chondroitin
evidence_summary: RCTs show modest joint pain and function benefits in OA, particularly when combined with glucosamine. Evidence for standalone chondroitin is less consistent. Perimenopause joint health relevance.
dose_notes: Usually combined with glucosamine; bovine and marine-derived chondroitin available; quality and standardisation varies widely between products; shark-derived versions face sustainability concerns.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs and comparison of chondroitin sources are lacking.

synonyms: Methylsulfonylmethane; as MSM; dimethyl sulfone; DMSO2
evidence_summary: RCTs show anti-inflammatory and joint pain benefits, particularly in OA and exercise-induced muscle soreness. Often combined with glucosamine/chondroitin. Well tolerated.
dose_notes: Generally well tolerated; may have anti-inflammatory additive effect with glucosamine and chondroitin; derived from DMSO chemistry — sulphur-containing compound.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are limited; combination with glucosamine/chondroitin vs standalone not well established.

synonyms: Arthrospira platensis; as Spirulina; blue-green algae; Spirulina maxima
evidence_summary: RCTs show antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, blood glucose, and lipid management benefits. High protein content and micronutrient density. Heavy metal contamination risk with low-quality sources.
dose_notes: Heavy metal (lead, mercury, arsenic) contamination risk with non-certified sources — quality certification critical; may cause nausea at high doses; contains phenylalanine — avoid in phenylketonuria; some thyroid iodine relevance.
research_gaps: Post-2022: quality and contamination concerns highlighted; perimenopause-specific RCTs are absent.

synonyms: Chlorella vulgaris; as Chlorella; green algae; Chlorella pyrenoidosa
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for detoxification, cholesterol, and nutritional supplementation. Heavy metal binding properties studied. Limited perimenopause-specific data.
dose_notes: Heavy metal contamination risk — quality certification important; may interfere with warfarin (vitamin K content); gradually introduce to prevent GI upset; contains iodine — relevant for thyroid.
research_gaps: Independent high-quality RCTs for perimenopausal applications are essentially absent.

synonyms: as Activated Charcoal; activated carbon
evidence_summary: No RCT evidence for detoxification in healthy individuals. Used medically for acute poisoning. Significantly interferes with absorption of all supplements and medications if taken simultaneously. Should not be used as supplement.
dose_notes: AVOID co-administration with any supplement or medication — activated charcoal absorbs virtually all oral compounds non-selectively; no evidence for detoxification in healthy people; may cause constipation; interferes with nutrient absorption.
research_gaps: No credible evidence base for wellness detoxification claims; significant risk of supplement/medication interference.

synonyms: CoQ10 100mg+; as High-dose CoQ10; Ubidecarenone 100mg
evidence_summary: At doses above 100mg, absorption efficiency decreases. Some specific clinical applications (migraine prevention, Parkinson's, heart failure) use 300-1200mg. Standard perimenopause supplementation needs are typically met at 100-200mg.
dose_notes: Fat-soluble — take with fatty meal; divided doses (morning and lunchtime) preferred above 200mg; choose solubilised or nano-emulsion forms for superior absorption at higher doses.
research_gaps: Optimal dose range specifically for perimenopausal energy and cardiovascular outcomes not established.

synonyms: as Nattokinase; subtilisin NAT; NSK-SD
evidence_summary: Limited RCTs show fibrinolytic and blood pressure lowering effects. Significant anticoagulant activity. Derived from fermented soy (natto). Perimenopause cardiovascular relevance but significant drug interaction concern.
dose_notes: Significant anticoagulant/fibrinolytic activity — CONTRAINDICATED with warfarin, aspirin, clopidogrel and other anticoagulants; stop 2 weeks before surgery; not suitable with HRT-related cardiovascular monitoring without medical oversight.
research_gaps: Anticoagulant interaction profile in perimenopausal women not well characterised; small RCT base.

synonyms: as Serrapeptase; serralysin; Serratia peptidase
evidence_summary: Limited and inconsistent RCT evidence for anti-inflammatory and pain relief applications. Derived from Serratia bacteria. Anticoagulant properties. Evidence base weak compared to NSAIDs.
dose_notes: Enteric coating required for oral bioavailability; anti-platelet/anticoagulant effects — caution with blood thinners; limited robust RCT evidence; take on empty stomach.
research_gaps: Evidence base is thin and inconsistent; perimenopause-specific applications not studied.

synonyms: GSE; Citrus paradisi seed extract; as Grapefruit Seed Extract
evidence_summary: Antimicrobial properties primarily studied in vitro. Oral RCT evidence for systemic benefits limited. Significant CYP3A4 inhibition — major drug interaction risk.
dose_notes: SIGNIFICANT DRUG INTERACTION: inhibits CYP3A4 — can dramatically increase blood levels of statins, CCBs, immunosuppressants, benzodiazepines and many other medications; avoid with multiple medications; antimicrobial evidence primarily in vitro.
research_gaps: CYP3A4 drug interaction profile makes this unsuitable for combination products without prescriber oversight.

synonyms: Bovine colostrum; as Colostrum; first milk
evidence_summary: RCTs show immune modulation, gut integrity, and exercise recovery benefits. Contains IgG antibodies, growth factors, and lactoferrin. Some GI health evidence. Not suitable for vegans.
dose_notes: Bovine-derived — not suitable for vegans or those with milk protein allergy; IgA and IgG content varies between products; generally well tolerated; some evidence for gut permeability.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific immune and hormonal outcome RCTs are absent.

synonyms: as Lactoferrin; bovine lactoferrin; apolactoferrin
evidence_summary: RCTs show iron absorption enhancement, antimicrobial, and immune benefits. Iron-binding glycoprotein from milk. Some evidence for gut health and bone density in postmenopausal women.
dose_notes: Bovine-derived — not suitable for vegans; iron-binding — take separately from iron supplements; well tolerated; apolactoferrin (iron-free form) and lactoferrin have different properties.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific bone and iron absorption RCTs are limited.

synonyms: Zingiber officinale; as Ginger Root; ginger extract; gingerol
evidence_summary: Multiple RCTs for nausea, anti-inflammatory effects, and blood glucose management. Some evidence for joint pain. Antiplatelet activity at high doses. Generally very well tolerated.
dose_notes: Anticoagulant/antiplatelet at high doses — caution with warfarin; take with food to reduce GI irritation; generally well tolerated at dietary levels; standardised to gingerols and shogaols.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific anti-inflammatory and metabolic outcome RCTs are limited.

synonyms: Capsicum annuum; Capsaicin; as Cayenne; TRPV1 agonist
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for metabolic rate, satiety, and topical pain. Oral capsaicin supplement evidence thin. Thermogenic effects modest in RCTs.
dose_notes: High doses cause GI irritation; topical forms have much stronger evidence than oral for pain; thermogenic evidence modest and transient; generally well tolerated at supplement doses.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific metabolic RCTs for oral capsaicin supplementation are absent.

synonyms: CoQ10 + PQQ combination; as CoQ10 PQQ complex
evidence_summary: Combination products lack independent RCT evidence. Each ingredient has separate evidence bases that may be synergistic but human combination RCTs are minimal.
dose_notes: Evaluate each component separately; no meaningful synergy-specific human RCT evidence; combination products driven by theoretical mechanism not clinical trial evidence.
research_gaps: No robust combination RCT evidence; theoretical synergy not validated in human trials.

synonyms: Polaprezinc; L-carnosine zinc chelate; as Zinc Carnosine
evidence_summary: RCTs show benefit for gut mucosal repair, H. pylori eradication adjunct, and GI integrity. Different from zinc and carnosine separately — unique chelated compound. Perimenopause GI health relevance.
dose_notes: Unique chelated compound; distinct from separate zinc and carnosine supplementation; licensed as medicine in Japan; GI mucosal protective applications; take with or after food.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific GI health RCTs are absent; most evidence from gastroenterology settings.

synonyms: Pineapple enzyme; as Bromelain; pineapple protease
evidence_summary: RCTs show anti-inflammatory and sinusitis benefits. Some evidence for muscle recovery after exercise. Antiplatelet activity. Often combined with quercetin and other anti-inflammatories.
dose_notes: Anticoagulant/antiplatelet — caution with blood thinners; may affect some drug absorption; take on empty stomach for systemic anti-inflammatory effect; with food for digestive enzyme effect.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific anti-inflammatory RCTs are absent.

synonyms: Bioperine; Piperine; as Black Pepper Extract; as Piperine
evidence_summary: RCTs show piperine significantly enhances bioavailability of curcumin (2000%), selenium, CoQ10, and other supplements by inhibiting intestinal metabolism. Standalone benefits limited at supplement doses.
dose_notes: CYP3A4 inhibitor — may interact with many medications similarly to grapefruit; at supplement doses (5-20mg), interactions are generally clinically minor but caution with narrow therapeutic index drugs; Bioperine is standardised form.
research_gaps: CYP3A4 inhibition magnitude at supplement doses (5-20mg) in perimenopause populations and interaction with multiple simultaneous medications not established.

synonyms: as Copper Bisglycinate; chelated copper; copper glycinate
evidence_summary: Limited standalone RCT evidence; copper is an essential cofactor for iron metabolism, collagen crosslinking, and superoxide dismutase antioxidant activity. Bisglycinate form offers superior bioavailability versus gluconate or sulfate forms.
dose_notes: Commonly included to offset copper depletion from zinc supplementation; bisglycinate form preferred for tolerability; upper tolerable limit 5mg/day.
research_gaps: Independent perimenopause-specific RCTs are absent.

synonyms: as Potassium Citrate; potassium; dipotassium citrate
evidence_summary: RCTs support potassium for blood pressure management and kidney stone prevention. Electrolyte balance relevant to perimenopausal cardiovascular health. Most dietary potassium should come from food.
dose_notes: EU supplements limited to 99mg per daily dose in many jurisdictions due to cardiovascular risk at high supplemental doses; blood pressure medication interaction; caution in renal impairment; high-dose supplementation requires medical oversight.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific cardiovascular supplementation RCTs using potassium are limited.

synonyms: Salt; NaCl; as Sodium; sodium chloride
evidence_summary: Electrolyte; not supplemented in women's health supplements for nutritional benefit — relevant only as excipient or in electrolyte formulas. Excess sodium associated with hypertension and calcium excretion.
dose_notes: Most women consume excess sodium from diet; supplemental sodium only appropriate in electrolyte/sports contexts; sodium ascorbate is common vitamin C form that contributes sodium.
research_gaps: Not applicable in typical women's health supplementation context.

synonyms: Phosphate; dicalcium phosphate; as Phosphorus; DCP
evidence_summary: Essential mineral but widespread in diet; supplementation not appropriate in otherwise healthy perimenopausal women. Used as excipient (DCP) in tablets. Excess phosphorus impairs calcium and magnesium absorption.
dose_notes: Dicalcium phosphate commonly used as excipient/filler in tablets; adequate phosphorus is easily obtained from diet; supplementation not recommended in typical healthy perimenopausal women.
research_gaps: Not applicable for supplementation in healthy perimenopausal women.

synonyms: ResistAid; as Larch Arabinogalactan; arabinogalactan; AG
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for immune modulation and prebiotic activity. Soluble fibre with bifidogenic properties. Some evidence for NK cell activity. Relatively few high-quality trials.
dose_notes: Generally well tolerated; mild gas and bloating possible; soluble fibre prebiotic activity; limited independent clinical evidence base.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs are absent; limited evidence base compared to established prebiotics.

synonyms: Brewers yeast; Nutritional yeast; as Saccharomyces cerevisiae; selenium yeast; chromium yeast
evidence_summary: Used as substrate for selenium and chromium yeast; whole yeast has B vitamin mineral and beta-glucan content. Beta-glucan from yeast has immune modulation evidence. Not the same as S. boulardii probiotic.
dose_notes: Different from Saccharomyces boulardii probiotic strain; good source of B vitamins and minerals; yeast beta-glucan has different immune evidence from oat/barley beta-glucan; avoid in yeast allergy.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific clinical outcomes using S. cerevisiae supplementation are not well established.

synonyms: Anthocyanins; Pterostilbene; as Grape Skin Extract; red grape polyphenols; OPC
evidence_summary: Limited RCT evidence for cardiovascular and cognitive benefits. Contains anthocyanins, pterostilbene, and OPCs. Pterostilbene may be more bioavailable than resveratrol. Limited perimenopause-specific data.
dose_notes: Pterostilbene (methylated resveratrol analogue) has better bioavailability than resveratrol; anthocyanin content varies widely between products; mild anticoagulant activity.
research_gaps: Perimenopause-specific RCTs for cognitive and cardiovascular outcomes are absent; standardisation varies.

synonyms: Euterpe oleracea; as Açaí; Acai berry extract; Açaí palm
evidence_summary: No meaningful human RCT evidence for any specific health outcome. Marketed heavily for antioxidant and weight loss claims. Antioxidant capacity in vitro does not translate to clinical outcomes.
dose_notes: Antioxidant capacity tests (ORAC) do not predict clinical benefit; weight loss claims unsupported by RCT evidence; no safety concerns at supplement doses but no demonstrated efficacy.
research_gaps: No clinical RCT evidence base exists to support marketed health claims.

synonyms: Punica granatum; as Pomegranate Extract; pomegranate polyphenols; Pomanox; ellagic acid
evidence_summary: Some RCTs show cardiovascular, blood pressure, and joint health benefits. Ellagitannins converted to urolithins by gut bacteria — variable individual response. Some menopausal symptom data.
dose_notes: Urolithin conversion from ellagitannins is gut microbiome dependent — variable individual response; Pomanox and PomellaTM are standardised extracts with human data; generally well tolerated; mild anticoagulant effect.
research_gaps: Individual response variation based on urolithin-producing microbiome status makes population-level efficacy prediction difficult.

synonyms: Mitopure; as Urolithin A; UA; ellagitannin metabolite
evidence_summary: Post-2022: Mitopure (Timeline Nutrition) has RCT evidence for mitophagy activation, muscle endurance, and cellular energy in middle-aged and older adults. Novel ingredient with growing evidence base specific to ageing populations.
dose_notes: Post-2022: Mitopure has now accumulated multiple human RCTs; urolithin A bypasses gut microbiome conversion step unlike pomegranate extract; generally well tolerated; novel ingredient with good safety profile to date; highly relevant to perimenopausal cellular health.
research_gaps: Post-2022: evidence base growing rapidly; long-term safety data (>12 months) and perimenopause-specific hormonal outcome data needed.
